BY rest is here meant the place of rest, as the temple and tabernacle are called God's rest, Psal. cxxxii. 14. This is my rest, here will I stay, for I have desired it: So Christ rests in his church according to his gracious presence, and displays the glory or his grace and goodness. The words teach us, that in the days of the gospel, Christ, as Lord and King or his church, shall gather a numerous people to himself, and establish a glorious and peaceable government among them; In that day there shall be a root of Jesse, which shall stand, &c.

IN further discoursing from these words I pro∣pose,
1. To consider Christ's character as here ex∣press'd.
2. The blessings of his government here promised. Lastly, Improve the subject.
THE first thing was, to consider our Redeemer's character as here expressed.

1. I SHALL consider how, and to whom he bears this character: It is a metaphorical way of speak∣ing, taken from armies, and military order: As all listed soldiers are obliged to follow their standard-bearer
and ensign; so every soldier of Jesus Christ must and will follow Christ and his cause. 1. Christ is an ensign by divine commission and appointment. He hath the Father's commission to this office. The glorious Leader of the saints did not enter upon his office without authority: He was no intruder, so he tells us, He was set up from everlasting, from the beginning, or ever the earth was. Had our Mediator taken upon him this office, without authority and commission, he would have been an usurper, and would have had no authority nor security for acceptance of his work, nor any re∣ward for it when finished. He was not like the false Christs that came before him, that were thieves and robbers; but he came from the father as his commissioned and sent servant. I am not alone, says he, but the Father that sent me is with me. That Christ was to be the ensign of the people he must have his commission sealed; and it is sealed with his Father's oath, I have sworn, says God, and will not repent, thou art a priest for ever. Christ as en∣sign of his church is King thereof; his standard is that of a King. His character as Ensign respects the evidence of his power; his character as king respects the authority with which he is invested: This authority he receives from the Father, as him∣self witnesseth, John xiv. 31. As the Father gave me commandment, even so I do. So he acknowledges as his servant, Thou art my servant, O Israel, in whom I will be glorified, Isa. xlix. 3. And in all the prophecies of him, and promises anent him, he is set forth as one having authority and a divine com∣mission, as one having a command and rule; for, says God, I have given him as a leader and com∣mander to the people, Isa. lv. 9. Our ensign rules by a royal warrant and power; he took not this to himself, but acts as the Father's servant; and as our Mediator he bears this character through the
whole of the Old Testament. Christ hath his com∣mission confirmed two ways, by writ and by oath: He says, Psal. xl. 6.7, In the volume of thy book it is written of me.

THE scriptures of the Old and New Testament are a volume where Christ's commission is contain∣ed, where his authority as ensign of the church is declared. The sacrifices, types and figures, all pointed at Jesus, as one having authority from God, to discharge this commission. The prophecies fore∣told that he would be such a person; the promises secured this; Behold a king shall reign in righteous∣ness, says the prophet, and says the Lord, I will bring forth my servant the Branch, Zech. iii. 8. The very first promise of the gospel pointed out Christ as one having authority, he shall bruise thy head.

HE hath his commission also by solemn oath; By two immutable things whereby it is impossible for God to lie, that we might have strong consolation he hath confirmed it by his oath: And speaking of Christ's kingly commission as a Mediator, Psal. cx. 4. he says, The Lord hath sworn, and will not repent; that Christ was to be governor and leader of his church: The Father gave him the surest ground to rest upon, for the acceptance of his service and as∣sistance in his work: For this reason he hath sealed his commission by writing and oath. This also is a sure ground of christian comfort in time of trial.

2. Christ is the ensign of the people by consecra∣tion: He was consecrated to this office in the most solemn manner: He was anointed to this office by the Holy Spirit, Psal. lxxxix. 20. I have found out David my servant: With my holy oil have I anointed him. As the ensign of the church he received the spirit without measure: Hence, says the church, Psal. xlv. 7. God thy God hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows. Jesus Christ as God, could receive no addition of spiritual unction, because he
was possessed of eternal fullness; but as the king of his church, and the leader of his people, he was qualified with a holy unction. This comprehends all his mediatory qualifications. In order that Christ should be the king and lawgiver of his church, it was necessary that the Spirit of the Lord should rest upon him, as in the second verse of this chapter where our text lies. Hereby he was made of quick understanding in the fear of the Lord. That his government might be a righteous government, it was necessary he should be filled with the spirit of righteousness: That he might fill all the vessels of his Father's house, it was necessary that in him all fullness should dwell. Moreover, Christ's human nature was consecrated with a special consecration. That he might be holy, harmless, undefiled, and se∣parated from sinners, it was necessary that his relati∣on to men should not make him impure as they were. Had he not been pure, and holy, and consecrated as to his human nature, he could not have been an ensign of holiness. The stately troops of kings and priests that follow this glorious ensign, must be conformable to him in holiness; and when he leads them it is in the ways of holiness. Had he not been consecrated by a holy divine unction, he could not have been free of that pollution that was com∣mon to all the posterity of Adam. That his human nature might be free of all impurity, it was sanc∣tified by the Holy Ghost; this is witnessed by the angels to Mary, Luke i. 35. The power of the High∣est shall come upon thee; and the holy Thing which shall be born of thee, shall be called the Son of God. Christ that he might be the only ensign of God to men, whom they ought to follow as their guide to glory, was consecrated in a threefold character, of prophet, priest, and king. His standard bears a relation to every branch of his character. The design of a standard-bearer is to lead, to save, and conquer:
Christ was anointed for all these purposes. That he might instruct and lead his followers in the ways of truth, he must be a prophet, and consecrated for that purpose. There were only three degrees of dignity under the Old Testament, for which it was necessary to consecrate the persons invested with it, by anointing them with oil, viz. prophets, priests, and kings. Christ was anointed in all these three characters, as worthy of the dignity thereby con∣ferred upon him, Psal. ii. 6. I have set my king up∣on my holy hill of Zion, with my holy oil have I a∣nointed him. He hath given him to be a light to the Gentiles, and placed him a prince upon his thrones, consecrated him in all these offices.

MOREOVER, Christ as the ensign of the people, must work out their salvation: This he must do by price as well as by power; and for this reason he must be a priest as well as a king, and a suffering Saviour According to the tenor of the covenant of grace, there was a price of redemption that our Redeemer Christ engaged to pay; a purchase he was to make of those that were given him of the Father, When he shall make his soul an offering for sin, he shall see his seed. His offering himself as our High Priest, a sacrifice for our sins, was a payment of that ransom price he engaged to pay. To com∣pleat our salvation, it was necessary he should also be a king; and for this end came he into the world, that he might also subdue all his and our enemies. The fulfilling of this character in our text is a com∣pleating of the conquest over sin and Satan, that was promised, Psal. cx. 6. He shall judge among the heathen, he shall fill the places with the dead bodies: he shall wound the heads over many countries. For these purposes he was consecrated, that he might answer his character as the ensign of the church.

3. CHRIST is an ensign by his own choice, and his peoples' consent. He willingly undertook this
office: When none among angels nor men could be found to save and lead the ruined posterity of Adam, our Redeemer says, Lo I come, in the vo∣lume of thy book it is written of me. With great chearfulness did our Redeemer embrace the office of a Saviour of his people. When he entered upon the execution of it, with what chearfulness and satisfaction did he fulfil the duties belonging there∣to. I have, says he, a baptism to be baptised with, and how am I straitened till it be accomplished? He set his face to go up to Jerusalem with great ear∣nestness and concern: It was as his meat and drink to do the will of his heavenly Father. He was free and voluntary; none could oblige him to engage on such an undertaking. He laid down his life for his sheep, which none could take from him: For he says, I have power to lay down my life, and power to take it up again. It was his own choice to be en∣sign of his people, and for this reason he submitted to death itself, as an evidence of his great delight in his choice. Before he could raise up a standard of triumph, he must first engage to approach an ab∣solute God alone; Who is this that engaged his heart to approach unto me, saith the Lord? Jer. xxx. 21. And the Redeemer himself says, Isa. lxiii. 3. I have trodden the wine-press alone, and of all the people there was none to help me.

BUT he is also ensign of the nations by the people's consent, Psal. cx. 3. Thy people shall be wil∣ling in the day of thy power. Though men by na∣ture are enemies to God by wicked works, yet in the day of Christ's power they are made willing; they leave all and follow him, like his disciples whom he chose in the days of his flesh. They consent to be governed by his laws, and delight in him as their law giver. Though in their uncon∣verted state they might be ready to say, we will not have this man to rule over us, yet in the day
of espousals and union to Jesus, they change their language, they say, The Lord is our judge, the Lord is our lawgiver, he is our king and will save us. The laws of Christ are their study, they account his yoke easy, and his burden light, and delight in the law of God after the inward man. His cross is also their glory; like the Apostle, they say, God forbid that I should glory, save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, whereby the world is crucified unto me, and I unto the world, Gal. vi. 14. They make choice of his statutes as the men of their right hand, and pray that they may keep them; with holy David they say, Incline my heart to keep thy law. The paths of righteousness are their chief delight, I will run the ways of thy commandments, when thou hast en∣larged my steps, says the Psalmist. The ordinances of God are their choice above all things, and they love the place where his honour dwells: They re∣joice when it is said unto them, Go up into the house of the Lord: Their hearts pant as the hart for the water brooks; and a day in God's court is better than a thousand elsewhere. Like David they will even en∣vy the swallows and sparrows that lodge in the sanctuary, when they cannot enjoy communion with Christ there.

THE promises of the covenant (of which Christ is Mediator) are their choice, for comfort in their affliction, and reasons of triumph in their enlarge∣ment. In their sorrowful moments, they draw wa∣ter with joy out of these walls of salvation, Isa. xii. 2, 3. and suck comfort from these breasts of consola∣tion. A true saint can enjoy more comfort in a promise of the new covenant, than the worldly can from his corn, his wine, and oil: They can hope when their tribulation abounds, and say with the Psalmist, Psal. cxix. 49, 51. In all my straits I am revived by thy word alone. When one disappoint∣ment succeeds another, and temptation after tempta∣tion
make them fall; yet they can say, One thing have I desired of the Lord, and that will I seek after, that I may dwell in the house of the Lord all the days of my life. Though I fall, I shall arise; though I sit in darkness, the Lord shall be a light unto me. The remembrance of his faithfulness in former experi∣ences, makes them rest in hope of the full fruition of all grace and glory with God for ever. More∣over, they chuse his people for their companions in the house of their pilgrimage; the society of good men they love and delight in: Whoever attends Christ's standard, they love to follow. The poor followers of Jesus will afford them more satisfaction, than the society of princes or ministers of state, of an opposite character.

4. CHRIST bears his character by proclamation. He is proclaimed king in the church, his kingdom in the most visible manner. He is proclaimed in heaven, and proclaimed on earth. All the glori∣fied saints in heaven proclaim him ensign of the people, Thou art worthy to receive glory, honour, and praise. The hallelujahs about the throne, are so many proclamations to the glory and praise of the Redeemer as the ensign of his people. Though we have but very faint conceptions of the manner of Christ's being proclaimed in heaven, in this our imperfect state, yet it is a truth, that all the heaven∣ly host proclaim him ensign of the nations. King of saints and king of nations, are striking accents of their proclamation. In this proclamation all the heavenly host are employed; there are no specta∣tors there. The elders cast down their crowns at his feet and cry, Thou art worthy, for thou wast slain and hast redeemed us to God by thy blood. Christ is proclaimed here by universal consent: Angels join with the saints in this glorious work. An evidence of this we have, in their readiness to proclaim him upon earth, when he came to the world as the en∣sign
of the nations. These ministering spirits bring down the language of heaven to this world, and teach the militant church the manner of Christ's proclamation.

JESUS is also proclaimed on earth. The angels brought down a copy of the proclamation to the shepherds, Glory to God in the highest, peace on earth, and good-will towards men, is the substance of this proclamation. The Apostles and ministers of Jesus, have carried on this proclamation ever since: John the Baptist was the first New Testament herald that took up this proclamation; he proclaimed him as the Lamb of God, that taketh away the sins of the world. The gospel is nothing but a proclamation of Jesus as the ensign of the people. Those who publish any other, in the gospel proclamation, but Christ, neither follow the copy of the angels, nor the practice of the triumphant church. Christ, as the glorious ensign of the people, exhausts all the proclamations in heaven, and should fill up all these upon earth. Christ in the gospel is proclaimed king and ensign, in his grace and fullness, his power and glory. The gospel is a proclamation of good and glad tidings to sinners, and it is only so, as far as Christ the ensign of the church is the substance of it. The gospel proclaims Christ as an ensign that liberates the captive, and sets free the prisoner, Isai. lxi. 1. This might bring us more par∣ticularly to consider, to whom he bears this cha∣racter. I have through the whole of this discourse viewed him as the ensign of his church; but it may be necessary to consider, what period of it our text more especially refers to, and what people this office views more immediately.

IT is the Gentile church, more especially, that Christ bears this relation to. This will appear if we consider the name given to the Gentile church; she is called the christian church, and that because
the members of it have enlisted themselves under Christ's banner; because they acknowledge Jesus, as the Lord and King of his church. When the Lord Jesus first set up the New Testament church, his name was the standard they adhered to: His name was the test what opinion men were of, whe∣ther Heathen, Jew, or Christian. Those that owned the name of Jesus, as the Saviour of the world, were called christians, or members of the christian church. The name of Christ was the standard to gather people to his cause, and it was promised that the gathering of the people should be to him under the name of Shiloh. The Gentiles when they first left paganism, were received in the christian church by acknowledging the name of Jesus, as the name whereby men only could be saved. So the christi∣ans, in the first days of christianity, had Christ's name written upon their colours, when they went out to war against the heathens; and none were re∣ceived into their armies that did not own and ac∣knowledge that name.

THIS was a very eminent fulfilment of the pro∣mise in our text, That he should stand as the ensign of the people. The name of Christ was the ensign of christians in that period, and a literal fulfilment of this promise. This was the first period our text re∣fers to, and it is remarkable what progress Christ's standard made in that period: The little cloud like a man's hand, soon became great and covered the hea∣vens: The handful of corn on the top of the mountain, soon became like prosperous fruit: Like trees on Le∣banon. How admirable was it for a few fishermen publishing the name of their deceased master, so to propagate christianity, that in a few centuries the christian name made no small part in the public speculations and interests of men. The name of Christ, as the ensign of the people, was the stan∣dard in the period of persecution. The name of
Christ was then the standard, under which the church sealed her testimony with her blood. In this period he was a bloody ensign; his garments were stained with blood. Those who adhered to the name of Jesus, suffered the most cruel barbarities; and his name was every where spoken against.

BUT even at this time the witnesses of Jesus, by adhering to his standard, overcame by the word of their testimony. When these faithful witnesses kept their eye upon Christ, as their glorious stan∣dard-bearer, they feared no danger, but suffered chearfully. The connexion between Christ's stan∣dard and victory, made these worthies stand by their ensign, and fall gloriously. Moreover, Christ was the ensign of his servants, who began and car∣ried on our reformation from popery. Christ's stan∣dard was of another sort. He was still himself en∣sign of the people; but now his standard was for his supremacy in his church. In the former pe∣riods christians contended for Christ's name in ge∣neral, in opposition to paganism; but now they contend for his priestly and kingly offices. Christ was an ensign against heathenism at first, but now he takes the field against antichrist. Jesus as the Lord, our righteousness and salvation, was the stan∣dard-bearer against popish works, pardons, and indulgencies, and against the tyranny of the Ro∣mish beast, over the souls and consciences of men. Now the truth of his imputed righteousness, as the ground of our hope before God, was the standard to hold by or desert. His authority, as the alone ensign of his saints, was now the matter of testi∣mony. Now it was, that Christ the ensign of his people, spirited a multitude of his servants to op∣pose these absurd and antichristian abominations. Christ was now ensign against his implacable ad∣versary, the Man of Sin: His standard was now in opposition to this murderer of souls. The oppo∣sers
of these antichristian abominations, did not promise great things to their followers; they only proclaimed their king, and shewed his colours. People were not at this period under compulsion to follow Christ's standard for fear of rack and tor∣ture: The followers of the lamb used no such car∣nal weapons, nor Mahometan engines: They used no force, but the evidence of their ensign's right to men's services, and the advantages to be ob∣tained under his banner. They displayed their banners in the name of the Lord; and when they fell in his cause, it was beside his standard. This was a remarkable period, when Christ's glory was made great as the ensign of his people; so great was the evidence of his power, that his standard made the powers of hell and Rome to shake.

BUT the words of our text may yet look forward to the latter days, when Jews and Gentiles shall be∣come one, and list themselves under Christ's banner, as the ensign of the people. The conversion of the Jews seems to be pointed at in the verse following our text, And the Lord shall set his hand the second time, to gather his people that are scattered, &c. Then shall Christ be an ensign to all nations, both Jews and Gentiles: The cross of Christ shall be no longer a stumbling block to the Jews, but they shall flock to his standard, and submit to his govern∣ment: As the Gentiles shall seek to his standard from afar, so shall also the Jews, and great shall be the peace of the kingdom. The glory of Christ as the King of his church, shall in these days be far more evident and conspicuous, when out of all nations and kingdoms, his brethren according to the flesh shall seek after him. Whether Christ shall bring that ancient people into their own land, and place them in a state of civil government, I shall not take upon me to determine; though it may be presumed that it will be so, from many promises of the Old
Testament, and some passages in the New, as Ezek. xxvi. 7, 24, 25, 26. These promises were not wholly fulfilled at their return from the Babylonish captivity, because at this very day they are a re∣proach among the nations whither they are scattered abroad. But when they are brought again into their own land, in that day the promise refers to, they shall be no more a reproach to the nations, and the heathen about them. It is promised they shall dwell in their own land, and enjoy the promised blessings of the new covenant; but this they have not yet done; therefore it is reasonable to think that they shall yet have a glorious kingdom, both as a church and state.

UNDER the reign of the Messiah, the drying up of the river Euphrates is prophesied of, which seems to refer to that glorious day, when Christ shall be the ensign to both Jews and Gentiles. The Mahometans, that now possess their land, shall fall at the battle of Armagiddon; and it is probable that the Jews shall enjoy their own old possessions in that day. Be this as it will, it is certain, Christ shall be the ensign of his people after all these commo∣tions are at an end: And he shall stand as an ensign of the people; to him shall the Gentiles seek, and his rest shall be glorious.
Head 2. To consider the blessing of rest, pro∣mised under Christ's government.

1. WE may consider the glory of the gospel church in the purity of her doctrines, worship, and the number of her converts. She is glorious in the purity and simplicity of her doctrine. Every thing necessary to be believed and practised are pure and plain, Psal. xix. 7. The law of the Lord is pure. The testimony God hath given of himself in the gospel, as our God and Saviour, is most pure and plain. God's declaration in his word of
peace, are free of every tendency to impurity. Where the doctrines of the gospel are believed, they will issue in holiness. There is no tendency in any article of the christian religion to impurity. The more strong the faith of a christian is, the stricter will his life be. If we may judge of a cause from its effects, we cannot but be persuaded that the doctrines of faith are pure, when all true believers of these doctrines are a holy people. Though many professing christianity live bad lives, it is no argument against its doctrines, but an evidence that they are unsound believers: For if they believed the purity of its doctrines, they would study to conform their lives to its holy precepts.

DID men believe God's testimony anent a wicked world, That it shall be ill with the wicked, for they shall eat the fruit of their doings, is it possible they could any longer live either indolent or bad lives? The very design of the Almighty's revealing to men the danger of sin, and the state they naturally are in, is that they may believe it, and turn from it to Christ in a pure and holy manner. In the first chapter of this prophecy, he sets before Israel a description of their ruined state and condition; and in the 18th verse, shews the reason of this awful de∣claration; namely, That they might be holy, Though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be white as wool; though they be as crimson, they shall be like snow. Moreover, these doctrines are delivered in the most simple and plain manner, free of all su∣perstition and gaudy ornament. They are set forth as they really are, true and pure. Though we have in the scriptures lofty descriptions of the power and majesty of God, beyond the parallel of human rhetoric; yet all the grounds of faith and rules of practice, are exprest in the plainest and most simple manner. We are indeed obliged to believe many things we cannot fully comprehend, as being be∣yond
our full reach in this imperfect state; yet, properly speaking, we are not called to believe any thing beyond the reach of our capacity: For what is the ground of our faith, is the testimony and declaration of God; which any person of common understanding may comprehend as a truth, though he cannot comprehend all the properties of the object revealed, nor all the reasons of the truth declared.

THE reason of our belief is clear and plain, the pure and perfect law of God. And if we believe that God is, and that he is an absolutely perfect being; then his declaration is sufficient to assure us, that any thing not repugnant to reason is true, though it be above our present capacity. God can∣not deceive us; therefore to believe his word can never be unsafe, but profitable. Must not then the church be very glorious in point of faith, when she is certain that in believing God's word she cannot err? What the church of Rome falsely assumes to herself, the church of Christ may with certainty claim as her privilege, namely, infallibility in faith: But then the articles are not of her own framing, but framed by the spirit of God; they derive not their authority from herself, but from her God and Saviour. This is an excellent branch of glory be∣longing to the church of God, that her faith is sure and certain, and the doctrines upon which it is founded most pure and true. They are free from the vain additions of men; have their authority imme∣diately from the Almighty, and are neither more or less true or false, pure and holy, by the sanction of men or the authority of churches. In this the New Testament church has by far the advantage of the Old; as every christian may believe for himself, and embrace the doctrines of religion, without in∣curring the divine displeasure for not agreeing with any national establishment. In matters of the most
solemn nature, the worshippers of God then, could not approach unto him but by the intervention of priests and sacrifices, and were not allowed to enter within the vail; but christians, under the gospel dispensation, may approach unto the holiest of all by the blood of Jesus, and offer the sacrifices of praise and thanksgiving to God, without the in∣tervention of priest or clergyman. The true be∣liever under the gospel, may see the purity of doc∣trine, and the evidence thereof as the ground and rule of faith, as it were at first hand; whereas these worthies had a long train of mediums to look through, that were dark in themselves, and but shadows in comparison of what we now enjoy. The discoveries of the gospel are farther advanced beyond these under the law, than all the modern disco∣coveries in philosophy are beyond the ancient.

THE doctrines anent the restoration of men into the divine favour, are pure and spiritual: The souls of true believers may enjoy communion with God thereby, by the assistance of his grace, without any second editions from men or churches. Men now may make free with the promises, without asking liberty from priest or prophet. No person or per∣sons whatsoever can be lords of our faith or con∣sciences. The doctrines of salvation now run in a a free channel, which is the great glory of the christian church: Every man may now judge and believe for himself. Helps in the practice of reli∣gion we may and ought to have, but lords over our faith and conscience we cannot have, without destroying our christian liberty. The New Testa∣ment church is glorious in this respect, as every member, in what he is to believe and practise for salvation, is alike free. No worldly power or dig∣nity can give more or less liberty in matters of faith and practice. The poorest person that lives is as free in this respect as either kings or emperors.
This liberty arises from the truths themselves that teach it. Hence christian liberty is not founded upon the permission of churches and legislators, but upon the authority of God, expressed in the doc∣trines of his word. Every private christian has now the glorious freedom and liberty of reading the sacred oracles in his own language, and of understanding and believing them as he is able, without being account∣able to any but God himself. The doctrine of justification, through the imputed righteousness of Christ, without the works of the law, is purely and clearly taught in the gospel church: No mixture of popish works and pardons is joined with this me∣ritorious cause of our salvation; This pure water of life is clear like crystal, Rev. xxii. 1. The promises of life and salvation, are opened up in these glori∣ous days of rest in the church, as containing our ground of acceptance with God, and the cause of our meetness for eternal life. What Jesus did and suffered, and that he died and rose again, is freely set forth in the gospel: Nothing but plain truth is there published, free from the disguise of the en∣ticing words of man's wisdom: No conceits of de∣signing men are joined with these doctrines, nor mixed with the history of the life of Jesus, but a pure declaration of what he did and suffered; and for what end and purpose is exhibited in the gospel.

No great things are required of men to come at these benefits which Christ purchased to his people, only faith in Jesus, and in what he did is required, which is also promised. For this purpose God hath promised his spirit to assist us, Ezek. xxxvi. 27. I will put my spirit within you, &c. The two Testaments are so pure and simple, and free of ob∣scurity, that no objection can be justly made against them, either from themselves or the manner they are delivered. We have truths told us, by men who could have no design to impose upon the world,
and confirmed by the divine approbation, in work∣ing of miracles of support the evidence of these doc∣trines. Many of the things themselves are facts that none could deny; but in the way, contradicting themselves. When the Jews attempted to deny the resurrection of our Saviour, what a foul blun∣der did they fall into; they desired the soldiers to say that the disciples stole him away when they slept: But how could they be evidences when they were asleep? Must not such a cause be bad that needs such evidence to support it.

THE gospel church will appear glorious, if we consider these rules of practice that are given her for her observation. This comprehends all divine commandments and institutions. Under the gos∣pel we have a beautiful system of moral precepts, freed from all the ceremony of the figurative pe∣riod: Laws in themselves, founded in the nature of things, and tending to the happiness of such as obey them, are clearly taught in the divine law; a brief sum of which we have in the two great command∣ments mentioned by our Saviour; Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and thy neigh∣bour as thyself. This he more fully explains in his excellent sermon on the mount: There he shews what he expects from such as follow him, and what they shall enjoy by a sincere observation of his com∣mandments. The way of keeping the command∣ments is the way to heaven, though not the pro∣curing cause of our admission. The system of moral duties under Christ's government is more spi∣ritual than under the law, and no less necessary though less grievous. The temper and disposition of mind on which a christian discharges his duty, comprehending principle, motives and end, is more regarded by God than the pompous way of doing of it▪ The glory of Christ's government in his church, is very remarkable for the sweetness and
easiness of his yoke; His yoke is easy, and his burthen light. That blessed system of rules he hath laid down, and corroberates by his own example, is an easy and delightful path for his followers to walk in. What makes this yoke easy is, it being in his own hand; Scribes, Pharisees, and lawyers, have now no right, To bind heavy burthens upon men's shoulders: No set of men have authority from Christ to force men to religious duties, nor to add a heavy yoke of additional human inventions, to the ordi∣nances of Christ. The kindly Redeemer imposes the yoke of duty, and lays on the burthen of obli∣gation himself; which he enables his people to bear by the assistance of his Holy Spirit. When the rules of practice among the Jews came through the hands of Rabbies and Priests, what a heavy yoke did the people groan under? The law of Moses by them was augmented to a monstrous size, and the duties imposed by them upon the people were beyond all possibility of observation. These dicta∣torial Levites knew how to impose burthens upon the people, but were ignorant how to assist in the way of bearing them. It is a great mercy to the christian church that she is, by right from Christ, out of the domineering hands of priests and clergy∣men. She now receives her laws from Christ him∣self, who has the bowels of a parent, and the mercy of a God; and is not A severe master, who reaps where he hath not sown. Under the government of Jesus, the King of his church, his subjects serve him without fear. The administration of the Me∣diator is free of terror; for his people by him, Be∣ing delivered out of the hands of their enemies, serve him without fear all the days of their life. There was much terror at giving the law upon mount Sinai, so that Moses exceedingly feared and quaked; and all along there was something of terror attended that dispensation. The law was given with thun∣der,
and repeated with curses; and sundry remark∣able examples of divine vengeance were seen for the breach of some positive laws in that period. But under the gospel mercy reigns through righteous∣ness by Jesus Christ our Lord.

DIVINE laws now more immediately respect the consciences of men, and that visible severity which appeared in the first dispensation is sweetly tempered with grace under the government of the Messiah. If we view the ordinances and institu∣tions of the christian church, she will appear glo∣rious. The easiness of their performance, the happiness of their tendency, adds a considerable lustre to these institutions. The ordinance of preach∣ing the gospel, whereby peace and pardon is pub∣lished to sinners, is a noble and glorious privilege of the gospel church: This institution, as appointed by Christ, is glad tidings to all people: A gra∣cious design of heaven revealed to men, and a testimony of God's satisfaction with what Christ hath done. In the gospel God speaks to men from a throne of grace, and declares his mercy to sin∣ners through his beloved son.

THE gospel presents us with a more benign dis∣covery of the Deity; his goodness, grace, and mercy shine illustriously through this dispensation. God draws men now near him in the way of love, and the true gospel faith in God, as in Jesus recon∣ciled, is a faith that works by love. The amiable character of the Deity is represented in this dispen∣sation of the Redeemer's power; and the gospel method of saving sinners is a persuading them to embrace Jesus as revealed in divine revelation, As made of God unto us wisdom, righteousness, sanctifica∣tion, and redemption. The language of the gospel is, I am pacified towards you, for all the ill that thou hast done. The character of God in the gospel ap∣pears propitious to men, as he has declared his sa∣tisfaction
with what Christ hath done for their sins, through his obedience. The character of our Me∣diator as God in our nature, constitutes a friend∣ship between heaven and earth.

IN the gospel dispensation, the great rewards laid up for them that love God are beautifully opened up and displayed. That the saints shall enjoy everlasting rest in the favour of God through eternity, is clearly revealed in the gospel. The prophet tells us, That eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath it entered into the heart of man to conceive what God hath laid up for them that fear him. And what was hid from ages and generations is now brought to light by the gospel, even life and im∣mortality. In this dispensation of the Redeemer's government there also appears the greatest purity and holiness, as men are saved in the way of vin∣dicating the purity and holiness of the divine cha∣racter, by forming the minds of believers into the likeness of God. This gospel, though it represents God as gracious to such as accept of his son, yet it testifies that he is holy and just in punishing ob∣stinate unbelievers.

THE gospel is pure in all its offers and promises; it offers salvation to the guilty and unclean, but bestows it in the way of washing and cleansing them from all their iniquities; The blood of Jesus, his son, cleanseth them from all sin. The very offer of Christ contains holiness in the nature of it, as the cha∣racter in which he is offered testifies; For he is made of God to us, sanctification and redemption.

THESE ordinances of baptism and the Lord's supper, hold forth the glorious purity of the king∣dom of Christ, and that his rest is glorious. Bap∣tism points out a purification from the pollution of sin by the blood of Jesus, and all persons to whom this ordinance is blest and sanctified, are washed from the guilt of sin, And purified from dead works to serve
the living God. The institution of the supper acquaints us with the liveliest picture of strict holiness, as therein Christ is represented as crucisied, that a holy people might by that death enjoy communion with a holy Lord God. The very signisication of this ordinance is holiness; for the blood of Christ therein shewed forth, is blood that cleanseth from all sin, and such as partake of that ordinance oblige themselves to war against the devil, the world, and the flesh.

THIS is a glorious privilege of the New Testa∣ment church, that the friends of Christ may eat and drink in his presence, clothed with his pure and spotless righteousness. The spiritual nature of this ordinance is to nourish the soul in holiness, and to strengthen the faith of believers in every word of promised goodness. There is a more full and perfect representation of divine goodness and grace in the sacrament of the supper, than was in the passover of old. The Old Testament saints did eat in the presence of Christ, but did not drink, better things being reserved for us; but this or∣dinance points out that perfect satisfaction and joy in Christ, by a full representation of all that figures forth satisfaction, or is needful for nourishment, viz. eating and drinking. In this holy ordinance believers sit, and eat, and drink with Christ at his table, by faith, and as it were are brought to a state of rest, when compared with the Jewish church: They did eat the passover with their staff in their hand, as ready to enter upon a journey, but the church now, in token of a more glorious rest, is allowed to sit, and both to eat and drink, as an evidence of a more perfect state.

IN point of all parts of worship the church of Christ is glorious. Believers are not now confined to any one place to worship God, but in all places them that fear God and work righteousness, are accept∣ed.
There is a glorious freedom of access to God through Jesus, at all times and in all places. The Jews had to go up to Jerusalem once every year to keep the passover, and no place but that which the Lord had chosen was accounted acceptable: But under the gospel, christians are freed from that con∣finement. We may consider the glory of the New Testament church in the number of her converts: That promise, More are the children of the desolate than of the married woman, has been in a great measure fulfilled: This is clear from the beginning and progress of this branch of the church's glory. It began with great success; a nation, as it were, was born at once. After the out-pouring of the spirit upon the day of Pentecost, after our Lord's ascen∣sion into heaven, multitudes were converted to christianity; and Satan's kingdom was made to shake. Such was the powerful evidence that at∣tended the doctrines of the gospel, that no power of prejudice could oppose it: Its truth was so powerful and convincing, that men, over the belly of interest and pleasure, became followers of Jesus, and subjects of his kingdom. Men at this time broke through the strongest connexions of relation and friendship, and joined themselves to the church; They lest father and mother, sister and brother, and followed Christ. Worldly interest, that has the most powerful influence over the conduct of men, could not hinder the primitive christians to embrace christianity: If they had friends they left them, if possessions they sold them, and went over all dif∣ficulties to add to the number of Christ's soldiers. Even in Jerusalem, where Jesus was crucified, there was a numerous multitude of converts to the gos∣pel church: Peter, at one sermon, converted three thousand; and John, by another, five thousand. Never under any former dispensation do we hear of such a number of converts so soon made, and in
opposition to so many prejudices. This was a glory referred to the days of the gospel, when Christ should stand as the ensign of the people: This was a glory designed for Christ's New Testament spouse, and a crown wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his espousals.

WHEN we consider the opposition christianity met with, this beginning will appear glorious. No device of man was wanting, nor force to suppress the dawning of this glory. The Jews exprest the utmost fury and malice against the primitive chris∣tians: The rulers of the Jews supprest it all they could; They stoned Stephen to death, and slew James with the sword: They scourged others and treated them cruelly; but all this could not hinder the increase of the church's glory, nor the number of her converts; The more they were oppressed, they mul∣tiplied and grew. That the number of converts should increase in opposition to all human oppres∣sion, and laws made against christianity, is an evi∣dence of the glorious power of the grace of the Redeemer, operating upon the minds of men by the gospel. There were no promises nor prospect of worldly advantages that attended this religion to incline men to embrace it, but on the contrary they were forewarned that losses and persecution should be their lot. Could any thing but the glo∣rious evidence of divine truth, persuade men to engage in a cause, where they were sure of nothing in this world but trouble and persecution? Yet so it was, that at the very beginning the church was glorious in the number of her converts. As the beginning of christianity was glorious, so the pro∣gress it made was remarkable. That handful of corn upon the top of the mountains soon began to shake with prosperous fruit, like the trees in Lebanon. Those few apostles and converts at Jerusalem, by the per∣secution that arose there, were scattered abroad,
and preaching the gospel to the Gentiles, converted multitudes to the faith of Jesus. In a short time the number of christians multiplied to such a de∣gree, that they became considerable in the world, and bare no small proportion in sundry parts of the empire: The glory of the church of Christ went out through the nations, and she became ter∣rible as an army with banners. Even Kings became nursing fathers, and Queens nursing mothers to the church: Then her glory went out through all the earth, and the promise in our text was punctually fulfilled; For his rest was glorious.

THE powers of darkness, as the gospel made progress, gave way, and were not able to withstand its power, nor to keep those that were under their influence. Such was the glory of Christ's power in his carrying on his work in the church, that it dispelled the darkness wherever it came: Satan fell as lightning to the ground before it. Christ now triumphed over principalities and powers, and reigned in his church, and shined forth before his ancients gloriously. The glory of this progress of religion appears in the liberty and freedom of it. There was no force nor compulsion used to bring men over to christianity: All the new converts to the gospel enlisted themselves freely under Christ's ban∣ner. In this day of the Redeemer's power his people were willing, and christians agreed in one to make Christ their head. The new converts to the christian religion, having freely and voluntarily en∣gaged in the service of Christ, they served him with resolution and chearfulness; and by having their hearts bent upon his service, became good soldiers of Jesus Christ: They became so expert in the christian warfare, and so resolute in the service of their master, that neither force nor fraud could overcome their fortitude. Then it was that the church looked fair as the sun, and terrible as an army
with banners. Sons and daughters were brought forth in the church out of all nations; and she was glorious, as being the mother of many children to Christ. As the primitive christians were the fol∣lowers of Christ by free choice, so they never com∣pelled any to christianity against their will: Force and compulsion were left to Mahomedans and their imitators: Christ's people were free and willing themselves, and wanted none but such as were wil∣ling to embrace their fellowship. Civil authority had not yet got footing among christians; nor was religion as yet ingrafted upon the state. The ori∣ginal pattern of the religion of Jesus was pure and undefiled, neither mixed with human inventions, nor attended with secular awe, interest or pleasure. The acknowledgment of Christ as dead and risen again, and ascended into heaven, and as the only Lord of his church, was all the confession of faith required of new converts: They had not yet learn∣ed the method of creed-making, nor the art of forging canons to bind men's consciences: Liberty was well understood, and faithfully practised as yet. It was when churches began to model themselves after the manner of monarchies and states, that creed-making came in fashion: When interest and ease were the attendants of religion, it was found necessary to guard the privilege against being o∣verstocked.

So long as liberty was understood and practised, religion encreased, and christianity flourished; di∣visions were unknown, and love among brethren prevailed: But when once pride and ambition made men grasp at power, liberty was enfringed, love abated, and divisions commenced. No sooner did christians deviate from primitive freedom and li∣berty, than the glory of the church was defaced. Christ, as the ensign of the people, never intended any force in his system of government; all his sub∣jects
must be willing, otherwise they are not ac∣ceptable. The peace and harmony of the church depends upon her liberty, for without it there can be no true peace: When men are confined in their way of thinking in religion by others, they never will live in harmony: For every christian having the same privilege from Christ, can never see the propriety of others depriving them of it without his authority. The promise in our text, looks for∣ward to a time of liberty and peace, when the peace of the children of God shall be great; when brotherly love shall continue; when the hearts of christians shall be opened to receive one another with love, and shall not longer shut their fellow-christians out of their affections, from an attachment to some peculiar way of thinking. When this glory of the latter day is made to shine, men shall not longer judge their brethren, nor seek to square their con∣sciences by their own rules, but allow them to live and believe as the word of God directs them: Then shall that promise be amply fulfilled, Ezek. xxxiv. 25. They shall dwell safely in the wilderness, and sleep in the woods. For in that day there shall be a root of Jesse, which shall stand for an ensign of the people; to it shall the Gentiles seek, and his rest shall be glorious.
I SHALL now conclude this subject with a very short improvement.

1. From what has been said, we may see, that our Lord Jesus Christ answers his character given him in our text, as the ensign of the people. He has lifted up a standard to the nations from afar in the gospel, and revealed himself as the captain of our salvation. He leads his people into all truth, as their leader, and as the captain of their salvation directs them in all their spiritual warfare, defends them against the force and fraud of all their spi∣ritual enemies. The experience of all believers
from the beginning until now, can witness that Je∣sus fulfills this character; David could say, My foot had well nigh slipt, but the Lord held me up; and unless the Lord had been my help when I was oppres∣sed, my soul had remained in the house of silence. Whoever follows Christ, as the ensign of the people, will find that he answers his character; for he leads them safely to the borders of his sanctuary, and gives them the victory over all their spiritual ene∣mies. Those who make choice of Jesus for their leader, will certainly be safe; for he has infinite power to uphold them, to protect and deliver them; He has an arm that is full of power, his hand is great in might. Those who trust in him shall never be moved, but be like mount Zion, endureth for ever. As to the evidence of his character, as the leader and ensign of the people, even his enemies have been obliged to acknowledge it. The Jews, who were the most inveterate enemies of Jesus, were forced from the evidence of his power to confess, that truly mighty works were done by him. Pontius Pi∣late, by the inscription of his cross, acknowledged him as King of the Jews, and as ensign of the people. The evidence was so strong that it forced conviction upon our Lord's greatest enemies.

2. WE may see wherein the glory of the church consists; it consists in rest and peace. Nothing is more glorious than to see brethren living together in unity. It is the truest evidence of their relation to Christ, and a bright mark of his image upon them. The glory of any thing in truth, consists in its goodness, and it is only so far as it is good that any glory belongs unto it: But the Psalmist has assured us, That it is a good thing for brethren to live toge∣ther in unity, Psal. cxxxiii. 1. All the pageantry of worldly grandeur, without love and peace, is an emblem of hell. And a profession of religion, without peace and unity, is only a religious way of
serving the interest of Satan. The glory of the church consists of the true enjoyment of the fruits of the spirit; of which peace is an eminent one. Whatever honour men of various oponions may take to themselves, on account of the orthodoxy of their opinions, yet if they be fractious and de∣vicive, and love not to enjoy rest and peace, they have no glory worthy the name: For where there is envy, there is confusion and every evil work.

3. SEE a rule to be observed in order to enjoy the rest here promised. Make choice of Christ for a leader in all your undertakings. He is the ensign of his church, held forth in the gospel as one who leads men to that everlasting rest that remains for the people of God. No wonder they perish from the way of rest that keep not Christ in their eye; for it is his office to lead men to everlasting life. He is the way, the truth, and the life, and such as follow him shall never be disappointed. The great reason of so many wandering out of the way of true rest and peace, is that they know not nor follow Christ: They are ignorant of his character and offices, and have no dependance upon him; and by trusting to themselves, they fall short of this glorious rest. Not to make choice of Christ for our leader, and to depend upon him, is unbelief; and no unbeliever can enjoy this rest: The Israelites could not enter in∣to rest because of unbelief; and no unbeliever shall ever be a partaker of this glorious rest that remains for the children of God. It is such as follow Jesus, and rest upon him by faith, that shall behold him in that glorious place of rest, where it may be said in the truest manner, that it is glorious.

Lastly, LET every one be exhorted to follow Christ's standard as the true way to happiness and everlading glory. This is no fruitless pursuit, nor endless enquiry; they shall enjoy rest at last. The present state is a state of trial, but it leads to rest and
peace to them that follow Jesus. Godliness hath great gain, having the promise of the life that now is and of that which is to come. The followers of the Lamb shall at last rest from their labours, and their works follow them. Though they are in this world like soldiers in the field of battle, under the go∣vernment of Christ, their warfare shall be accom∣plished, and they shall enter into rest. Those who suf∣fer with Christ shall also reign with him, and such as have faithfully followed his standard of truth here, shall enjoy a kingdom hereafter. For mo∣tive consider, that such as follow Jesus as their lea∣der are sure of safety, He leads them by the good skill of his hand to his holy habitation: None that ever trusted in him were disappointed. It is no perad∣venture whether such as follow Christ shall be happy: It is a glorious certainty; for both the church mi∣litant and triumphant bear testimony to its truth. The Psalmist bears witness to this, Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me all the days of my life: And I shall dwell in the house of the Lord for ever: And the saints in glory say, Thou hast made us kings and priests to our God.

DIV1.HEAD: SERMON III. The Title of our Redeemer as the Lamb in the Midst of the Throne, and his Administration of his Trust in that Capacity, opened up.

Q.P: For the Lamb which is in the Midst of the Throne shall feed them.

DIV1.P:
THE Apostle Paul tells us that Christ is both the author and finisher of our faith; and our text informs that all our spiritual nourishment here and hereafter, proceeds from him as the Saviour of his people. From the beginning of the fourth chapter to the end of the eleventh, the Lord represents to John the state of the church under the Roman Emperors, by sundry significant visions and glorious figures; such as a throne in heaven and a lamb in the midst of it, four beasts, four-and-twenty elders, thunders, seven trumpets, and an innumerable company of blessed wor∣shippers praising to God and the Lamb for ever and ever. The scene of this vision is said to be in hea∣ven, as in the beginning of the fourth chapter. Heaven in this book is sometimes taken for the church, as chap. xii. 1, and 7. I saw a wonder in hea∣ven, and there was war in heaven: But here it must be understood of the place where the blessed reside, such as Stephen saw at his death; or if we under∣stand it more complexly, as comprehending a re∣presentation of both the militant and triumphant church, as something relative to both is represented
in this vision, it will be more consistent with the scope; for John saw an innumerable company, be∣sides one hundred and forty-four thousand, which seem to denote the Gentiles, who could not as yet be in heaven, literally so called.

IF we view heaven as comprehending both states of men, this vision of John's may consist of a two-fold scene; a representation of the happy state of those that were actually in glory, and of those who should come there.

ACCORDING to our view of this scene, the throne upon which the lamb is represented as sitting, may be viewed as a throne of grace, or a throne of glory. Christ our Lord, whose death and dying love we are met this day to commemorate, is pointed out under the metaphor of a Lamb, in allusion to the paschal lamb of old, and upon a throne as having finished the work that was given him to do; Ha∣ving triumphed over principalities and powers. He is represented as upon a throne, as the reward of ex∣altation promised unto him when he should make his soul an offering for sin: This glory the church a∣scribes unto him, xv. 6. Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever: The scepter of thy kingdom is a scepter of righteousness. This throne of grace, which is so in relation to us in this present state, is the throne of glory to Christ and the triumphant church; and our Lord upon this throne, stands in relation to both. He is represented as in the midst of the throne, pointing out his full authority to rule as king of Zion, and to save and redeem his people as the administrator of the new covenant.

THE manner of his administration is pointed out by his title and the trust committed to him. His title is that of a Lamb, gentle and meek; his trust is to keep and feed his people; The Lamb that is in the midst of the throne shall feed them.

IN further discoursing upon the subject, I pro∣pose,
First, to explain our Mediator's title here given him. Secondly, Open up his administration of his trust, as the nourisher and feeder of his people. Lastly, Improve the subject.
Head 1. To explain the title here given to our Lord and Saviour, namely of a Lamb.

1. IT points out the spotless purity and inno∣cence of his nature. He had no sin, nor was guile found in his mouth: So the Apostle tells us, Heb. vii. 2. Such on High-priest became us, as was holy, harmless, undefiled, and separate from sinners. It was necessary our Redeemer should be free from all sin, like a lamb without blemish or spot, that his obla∣tion might be acceptable unto God; for had their been any defect in his nature, or any sin cleaving unto him, he would have been an unfit and im∣proper sacrifice, and needed an atonement for him∣self. But as the paschal lamb, which was a type of him, was without blemish; so he, as the glo∣rious substance and signification of that type, was pure and free from all manner of sin.

HE had no original sin, being sanctified by the Holy Ghost, and born of a virgin in an extraordi∣nary manner: Nor had he any actual guilt by false imitation of wicked men; for he lived separate from sinners: His nature was pure, his manner of life strict and exemplary.

As he was positively innocent, so was he passively also. There was a positive natural holiness and purity in his soul and body: Every good qualification reign∣ed in perfection in his holy nature. Love to friends and enemies, a readiness on all occasions to do good to all men, were inherent in his nature. Love to God and every commandment of his holy law, needed not in him to be stirred up by motives, but were radically in his very constitution. It was as his meat and drink to do the will of his heavenly Fa∣ther.
His body was free of all positive seeds of corruption; so that when he was laid in the grave, the infection of corrupt nature did not seize his holy and blessed body: Being free of sin he was also free of the seeds of mortality. It was because it was necessary he should die, and not because it was natural to him that he yielded to death, and was laid in a grave. It is both natural and neces∣sary to men to die, because they have the seeds of mortality in their very constitution; and never can be freed from sin till they be freed from it by death. But it was not so with the Lamb of God, for he was innocent and spotless like a Lamb without all sin. Jesus was also passively pure and innocent; He gave no offence to the Jews nor the Greeks. When he was reviled, he reviled not again, but commended himself to him that judgeth righteously. Like a lamb, that can∣not hurt any thing, he behaved himself towards all men, both friends and enemies. When he had no call to exert his power to do good to any, he never used it to any man's hurt: He never spake nor acted to the disadvantage of any. Being pure and holy by nature, his whole life was a testimony of immaculate innocence and untainted rectitude: From his birth to his grave there were no inordi∣nate affections in his holy soul, nor evil actions in his hands: Even when he was highly injured, and most cruelly and unjustly used, As a sheep before his shearers is dumb, so he opened not his mouth.

2. THIS title contains in it his fitness for that trust that was committed unto him. He had re∣ceived the weighty and important trust of men's salvation: The Father gave him a seed to redeem, and he accepted of them; he engaged to pay the price of their redemption, which was to give him∣self a ransom for them; and as he became their High-priest, He behoved to have somewhat to offer. An imperfect or impure offering could not be ac∣cepted
of by a holy and perfect God, whose nature is holiness, and his law perfection: But Christ being holy, pure and perfect in the whole properties of his nature, was a fit and proper propitiation for the sins of his people: This the apostle Peter witnes∣seth, 1 Pet. i. 18. Forasmuch as ye are not redeemed with corruptible things, such as silver and gold; but with the precious blood of Christ, as of a Lamb with∣out spot.

OUR Lord being free of every imperfection, was exceedingly fit for honouring the holy command∣ment: He had both inclination and power to fulfil it. His holy will and inclination was natu∣rally bent towards all the precepts of the righteous law, and being free of all prejudices opposite there∣to, had full ability to fulfil all its commandments. His purity and holiness made him likewise a fit sacrifice to satisfy divine justice; For he was a Lamb without blemish. The strictest justice could find no imperfection in his obedience, nor insufficiency in his satisfaction. Concerning his perfect righteous∣ness, Jehovah says, I am well pleased for his righte∣ousness sake, Isai. xlii. 21.

HE every way answers this fair and innocent character given him of a Lamb. As the Lamb of God he was an appointed and consecrated sacrifice. The paschal lamb of old was set apart for a sacri∣fice by the Israelites, and for this purpose was kept from the tenth day of the month till the fourteenth; but had not there been a divine appointment, it would not have been accepted of: The law war∣ranting the institution was the safety of the people's conduct, and made the offering acceptable. Our Lord Jesus Christ was under an appointment of the Father, and consecrated by the Holy Spirit to be a sacrifice for the sins of his people. He was an ob∣lation by heaven's unchangeable law, and without an appointment he could not have been a propiati∣on
on without presumption. Answerable to his type the paschal lamb, he fulfilled his appointment; he suffered, that all things written in Moses and the pro∣phets concerning him might be fulfilled. The paschal lamb was not only a sacrifice but a feast; so our Lord Jesus Christ is both a feast and a sacrifice: His death was a sacrifice that satisfied justice, and it is also the food of the believer's faith. A believ∣ing view of Jesus, as the slain Lamb of God, is as real food to the soul of a true christian, as any cor∣poreal food is to his body: It strengthens our faith and credit in God, as reconciled to us, enlivens our affections and encreases our love. Our faith in God, as propitious to us through the blood of Christ, will raise our affections towards him who paid the ransom for our sins, and brought about our recon∣ciliation: It will kindle our love to him that loved us, and gave his only begotten son to die for us.

3. THIS title instructs us in the unchangeable nature of Christ's priesthood. He is still in heaven, as to character what he was while here, and bears the same offices for our salvation. Though he hath changed his state, he still retains the same office; he who was the suffering Saviour, or the Lamb for a burnt-offering, is the Lamb in the midst of the throne. This man continueth for ever, and hath an unchangeable priesthood, Heb. vii. 24. What he once offered in sacrifice for our sins, he now pre∣sents in heaven for our justification. Christ hath laid aside none of his offices, as our Mediator in heaven: He is the Light of the heavenly city, a Priest upon his throne for ever, of his kingdom there is no end: His dominion is an everlasting dominion. Though the paschal lamb was slain, its blood spake; and it was a constant security against the sin it was offered for, that it should not bring the people into con∣demnation, Though Christ was but once slain, his
blood still speaks peace to his people, and he pre∣sents the merits of his oblation before the throne of God, Heb. xii. 24. And ye are come to the blood of sprinkling, that speaks better things than that of Abel.

THOUGH Christ be in heaven, his blood speaks peace to men upon earth. He is still a faithful High Priest, in things pertaining to God, and makes reconciliation for the sins of his people. He is in the midst of the throne, as our advocate and interces∣sor, and ever liveth for that purpose, Heb. vii. 25. He is able to save to the uttermost all that come unto God by him, seeing he ever liveth to make reconciliation for us. It is necessary that Christ should continue in this character, that his people might have strong consolation. Christ, as our intercessor, hath fixt the anchor of our hope within the vail in himself, as the apostle expresseth it, Heb. vi. 18. That we might have strong consolation, who have fled for refuge to the hope that is set before us. The title that our Redeemer received in the new covenant transaction for our reconciliation, he still and ever will retain for our perseverance and everlasting confirmation These few things are implied in this title given our bles∣sed Redeemer as the Lamb in the midst of the throne.
Head 2. To open our Redeemer's administration of his trust, exprest in the words, the Lamb in the midst of the throne shall feed them.

1. LET it be observed that this is exprest in a figure, and is to be understood by analogy to our daily nourishment by the providence of God, as in him we live, move, and have our being. As our bodily frame is upheld and maintained by God, as the author of our providence, so our spiritual is maintained by him as our Lord and Saviour. The feeding of the saints, here or hereafter, proceeds from Christ, as the administrator of the covenant
of grace. As our bodies are supported by his bounty, so our souls are maintained by his grace and favour. What food is to the body, commu∣nion with Christ, in all his offices and relations, is to our souls; and a saint can no more live without this communion, than any creature can live without food or nourishment, Psal. lxxiii. 25. The spiritual ca∣pacity of the intellectual frame may be said to be fed, when such objects are presented to its contem∣plation as suit its nature, fill up its capacity, and satisfy its desires. Here it may be necessary to con∣sider what things Christ in his divine administration bestows upon his people for nourishment to their souls.

1. HE represents to their faith his love, as the surety of the new covenant, engaging for them as their surety priest, to fulfil all righteousness for them in the fulness of time; as Prov. viii. 23. I was set up from everlasting, from the beginning or ever the the earth was. A view of our Saviour's love as surety of the covenant, engaging for believers, when yet they were conceived as enemies to God, and obnoxious to his wrath and curse, must certainly be an entertaining subject to every heaven-born soul. When Christ by his Spirit reveals this in the doc∣trines and promises of the gospel to the soul, it is like good news from a far country; then with the apostle Paul the believer can say, He loved me, and gave himself for me, Gal. ii. 20. This is nourish∣ment to faith, when the soul is ready to faint un∣der apprehensions of divine anger. A view of Jesus, as the lamb in the midst of the throne, sustain∣ing the character of a surety for his people, and for such a soul in particular, will satisfy the spiritual disposition, as with marrow and fatness: Then can a christian say with the Psalmist, Psal. lxiii. 5. My
soul shall be filled as with marrow and fatness, and my mouth shall praise thee with joyful lips.

WHEN unbelief and the deceit of the evil one, darken the spiritual views of the true christian, marr his comfort, and introduce doubts and fears into the mind, make him question his right to the divine favour, the Redeemer presents to his soul what he is to him as his surety and salvation, and says, Let all thy wants be upon me. This is one of the first comforts the Lamb in the midst of the throne gives his people. The first solid satisfaction that the christian enjoys, after his embracing of Jesus, arises from a just view of him, as the high priest over the house of God. This gives him a sight of the pardon of sin, as his guilt is transferred upon his surety, and speaks a favourable release to the soul; If ye seek me, let these go their way: And as he is for ever appointed unto this office, the soul has here a lasting spring of comfort. Until the soul by faith in some measure sees its interest in Christ, as the surety of the covenant, it never can be truly satisfied, nor rationally delighted.

THE sure and rational views of Jesus; as a sure∣ty priest, bearing the sins of his people; and as their intercessor, agenting their cause before God, is true and suitable nourishment to a believer. It strengthens faith, encreases love, and raises a true joy in the soul.

CHRIST also represents unto his people the cause and end of his priesthood and suretyship: His free and unmerited love is that glorious cause there∣of, a most powerful and active one. This love is not merely an inclination towards their welfare and happiness; but a powerful determining principle, whereby he is influenced to do them good. The right understanding of this encreases the love of men to Jesus; for as this love in Christ appears to them as an everlasting powerful propensity to save
and sanctify them, they see a perpetual reason found∣ed in gratitude to love him. Their salvation, and liberty from sin and death, is the noble and excel∣lent end of our Redeemer's suretyship. He sub∣stitutes himself as our surety, that we might be freed from condemnation, and be a holy peculiar people to him, zealous of good works. All these re∣lations of his as a surety of the new covenant, are delightful to contemplate, and are spiritual nourish∣ment to the souls of christians. When he discovers these to his saints, he may be said to feed them.

2. HE feeds them with a discovery of the won∣derful constitution of his person, as God and Man, in two distinct natures, in one person. He opens up to his children the blessed relation he stands in to them, as bone of their bone, and flesh of their flesh, as their near kinsman that hath performed the kins∣man's part. This discovery is to the christian a ve∣ry delightful manifestation, whereby he is ready to declare his satisfaction in the Divine goodness, and to say, it is good for him to be here. To behold the nature of man united to the divine person of the Son, and exalted to a state of inconceivable bliss; and withal, to have the certainty that this is a pledge of our participation of the same glory in due time, cannot miss to be a satisfying discovery. This the Lamb in the midst of the throne opens up, and manifests to his people, his beloved ones: Whereby they anticipate, even in this life, fore∣tastes of the sweet enjoyment of the marriage sup∣per of the Lamb. It was such a discovery as this that made Job say, I know that my redeemer liveth, and that he shall stand at the latter day upon the earth; and though after my skin the worms shall destroy this body; yet in my flesh shall I see God: Whom I shall see for myself, and not another. A view of human na∣ture, united to the son of God, for all the ends and purposes of salvation, not in a mere passive sense,
as a redeemer from wrath; but as one that exalts the christian to the highest degree of felicity in the favour of God, must highly rejoice the souls of be∣lievers. When our Lord Jesus Christ manifests himself in his character, as Emmanuel, God with us, to his people, there is something so engaging in the discovery, that it fills up the whole attention of the mind, and satisfies all the desires of the soul. This discovery affords a great deal more contemplation than a finite capacity is capable of receiving or containing. Who can wholly comprehend this glorious mystery? This the angels desire to look into with pleasure: It is like food to their desires, but much more so to those souls who are admitted to view it and see their interest in it.

THE Saviour of sinners, as the Lamb in the midst of the throne, graciously admits his people into a view of the mystery of Godliness; this so delights their souls, and fills their spiritual capacity, that with Paul, 1 Tim. iii. 16. they cry out, Great is the mystery of godliness, God manifested in the flesh. There is something in this subject so entertaining, and satisfying to a rational being, given to spiritual contemplation, that of all others it begets the full∣est satisfaction in the soul. The glory of the Di∣vine mercy and goodness shines so illustriously here, that a being, sensible of its own guilt and imper∣fection, cannot but be delighted with the prospect. A relation of blood and kindred with the best of Beings; to be related to the God of heaven, in a nearness of flesh and blood, and have a right to say Emmanuel is our near kinsman, is a joyful consi∣deration.

3. HE opens up the sufficiency and fitness of his death, to procure his people freedom from wrath, and their admission into the Divine favour. This affords a joyful entertainment to the souls of his saints, as it is a salvation from the greatest of evils,
and the enjoyment of the greatest good. What can be worse than the displeasure of the Almighty: And what more delightful than his favour and ap∣probation? The apostle speaks in a feeling manner upon this subject: Who shall lay any thing to the charge of God's elect; it is God that justifies, who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died:—When we were sinners Christ died for the ungodly:—We have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ. Our Lord and Saviour as the administrator of the new covenant, when he manifests to the christian what the value and the end of his death is, as to him; and shews by the Holy Spirit his special interest therein; he enables him thereby to conclude, that he shall not die, but live, and discover the works of the Lord, Psal. cxviii. 17. This is like food and nourishment to his soul, by which he is enabled to run his christian race with joy. The most refined entertainment ne∣ver so much satisfied the delicatest taste, as such a view of the death of Jesus satisfies the soul of a true believer. A believing discovery of the death of Christ, as the cause of deliverance from spiritual and eternal death, is like a sweet and refreshing cordial to a fainting soul; a view of it as the cause of our admission into the favour of God, is like a plenteous feast to a strong and craving appetite.

THE blood of Jesus presented unto the faith of a true believer; or, which is the same thing, to a true persuasion of the sufficiency of his death, and its fitness for all the ends and purposes of salvation, is like a seal whereby the clearest right to an inhe∣ritance is impressed; which has a native tendency to rejoice the mind, and give satisfaction to those who have it. The Lamb in the midst of the throne, affords a lively display of himself, as slain and wounded for his people's transgression. Such a display made the church by the prophet say, Isa. lv. 5. He was wounded for our transgressions, he was
bruised for our iniquities, the chastisement of our peace was upon him, and by his stripes we are healed. The sufficiency and the fitness of the death of Christ for salvation, is like a fund of goodness laid up in store; for it is a sufficient price for all future spiritual en∣joyments; the whole of our future bliss and hap∣piness, is only the reward of this great work; and the Lamb in the midst of the throne, will thro' all e∣ternity feed his people with a view of the connection between his death, and that happiness they enjoy. The song of the redeemed from among men, is founded upon the death of Jesus:—Thou wast slain, and hast redeemed us to God by thy blood.

THE death and sufferings of Christ is so satisfy∣ing to those who understand it aright, that it be∣gets joy in the mind at every remembrance. It is a continued source of pleasure and delight, to all who see their interest in it: It was the subject of the apostle Paul's boasting and glorying, God for∣bid, says he, that I should glory save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, whereby the world is crucified unto me, and I unto the world. A literal view of the death of Christ, as an article of history, without considering it with a special view to ourselves, by faith of the operation of God, will afford no true satisfaction to our souls. Jesus our Saviour, by the powe of his Holy Spirit, brings his death near to the souls of his people, and presents it in the Divine testimony as an object of true and spiritual contem∣plation. This is what he presents you with this day in the sacrament of the supper; herein his death is shewed forth to all worthy receivers, and by faith it will become spiritual nourishment to your souls, and tend to your growth in grace, and advancement in holiness. Jesus tells his disciples, that his flesh is meat indeed, and his blood is drink indeed: That those who received it in a spiritual manner, should not die, but should live for ever. A view of the
sufficiency and fitness of the death of Jesus, must in consequence of all this be very satisfying to the souls of true christians, and a confirmation of the truth of the text, That the Lamb in the midst of the throne, still feeds his people in the midst of their enemies here below.

4. CHRIST feeds his people with the refreshing influences of his grace: He leads them beside the still Waters, Psal. xxiii. 2. Hereby they are enabled to improve all the former instances of his goodness; he satisfies them with his abundant grace. The Lamb in the midst of the throne leads them to living fountains of waters. This was the reason why Christ was anointed with the Holy Spirit above measure, that he might supply his people with grace in the time of their need. The saints in the day of conversion, receive the Spirit as the Spirit of quickening, by which they are made alive in Christ Jesus: But the Lamb in the midst of the throne, leads them deeper into the river of consolation. He gives new com∣munications of his grace to bring them forward unto perfection.
