The first principles of grace with∣out merit from Christ, as the head of influences, would decay; but as believers and He are united, he sends them new supplies of his goodness. He makes the river of life run continually into their souls, and refreshes their decaying spirits with the waters of divine consolation.

THEY have access unto the fountain of all goodness through him: Through him, says the apostle, we have access by one spirit unto the father. This is the cause of the continuation of their spiri∣tual life: The Spirit liveth and abideth in them. Were they to depend upon their own good endea∣vours for supply, their nourishment would soon come to an end, as the cause is both finite and im∣perfect; but their spiritual nourishment comes from above, from him who hath received gifts for men,
that God the Lord might dwell among them, Psal. lxviii. 18. As the glorious administrator of the covenant of grace, he bestows upon his church these gifts he hath received in trust, according to the va∣rious needs of the members thereof. When a live∣ly frame and exercise is ready to decay, and die away, he sends his quickening Spirit and revives his Zion, sends his word and heals her, Psal. cvii. 20. In all cases, and at all times, he is the Lamb in the midst of the throne, and will feed them.
THE last thing in the method was to make some improvement of the subject.

1. HENCE see what believers may expect at a communion table. Seeing Christ is the master of the feast, the entertainment will be according to the state of the king. He is the Lamb in the midst of the throne that is to feed you, O believing friend of Christ! He is vested with full power, and furnished with all fitness and sufficiency. He is Lord of his own house, and fills all in all; the whole that can make you happy through eternity is in his hand: In him doth all fullness dwell: The treasures of wisdom and knowledge are in him. You can conceive no bliss nor happiness suitable for your souls, but it is in him; for he is infinite, and possesseth all things, and hath promised to give them to you, according to your needs and wants. If you are his, all things are yours, whether Paul or Apolo, or life, or death, all things are yours, and ye are Christ's, and Christ is God's.

2. LEARN what is your duty in view of an ap∣proach unto God in this solemn ordinance: It is to come empty of yourselves, the Lamb in the midst of the throne must feed you. Think not to feed up∣on your experiences, your good endeavours, or for∣mer attainments: These are a deadly poison when substituted in the place of future dependance upon Christ. What you expect at the table of the Lord,
must not be your own, but Christ's: The Lamb must feed you and provide for you. All is of his own preparing, every thing is a free gift: This David witnesseth, Psal. xxiii. 5. Thou hast prepared a table before me, in the presence of mine enemies. Think not that you can have any thing to recommend you to God which Christ hath not given you. His righ∣teousness is the wedding garment, which only can make you approach acceptably to his table, and it is his own gift: The christian passover is wholly of his preparing.

3. SEE what this communion is which you en∣joy in the sacrament of the supper. It is the same in nature and kind with what the saints in heaven enjoy. The Lamb in the midst of the throne is the subject and author of both. The saints in heaven are fed with the same spiritual food: They are indeed of a larger capacity than you are in this imperfect state, and are capable of enjoying more of the Divine fulness than you are yet capable of; but they enjoy nothing of a different nature from what you enjoy. They can see farther into Christ's suretyship, the glorious constitution of his person as God in our nature, his death as our redeemer, the fulness of his grace, and the glory of his exal∣tation, than ye can yet do; but you feed upon the same food with the rest of his children: The Lamb in the midst of the throne feeds both the church mili∣tant and triumphant.

4. WE may see a difference between saints and sinners, in point of satisfaction to their souls. The one feeds upon the flesh and blood of the Son of God; the Lamb in the midst of the throne feeds them: The other feeds upon the sinful pleasures of a present world. They feed upon husks, in compari∣son of what the true christian is satisfied with. There is no real satisfaction in the empty pleasures that sinners are satisfied with; there is more of no∣thing
than reality in them, when applied to the soul; yea they are worse than nothing, for they are hurtful. The nourishment of the believer's soul is substantial, permanent and lasting. The food of the christian's soul is like its self, spiritual and im∣mortal; lasting as the nature of the soul.

Lastly, WE may see the love of God in Christ Jesus in preparing his christian passover; God so loved our world as to send his son to die for our sins, that through him we might have everlasting life: He gave himself to the death that we might live thro' him. Behold the love of God in giving up his Son unto a shameful and ignominious death for men that were his enemies, that they might have life and nourishment to their souls! Behold the love of the Son of God in cheerfully suffering the most exquisite torments that we might have food to our souls! Truly we may say with the Apostle; Behold what manner of love the father hath bestowed upon us that we should be called the sons of God! This ordinance of the supper is a memorial of love; of the dying love of our dear Redeemer, and ought to be observed with the highest love and regard to him. If he cheerfully died that we might live for evermore, we ought with all our hearts and souls to love him who loved us, and gave himself for us; for it is only such as love Jesus who will understand the meaning of the text, the Lamb in the midst of the throne shall feed them.

DIV2.HEAD: The Second PART of the SUBJECT.

Q.P: The Lamb in the midst of the throne shall lead them to living fountains of waters, and shall wipe all tears, &c.

DIV2.P:
IN the first discourse upon this subject we have taken a view of the administration of our Lord
Jesus Christ towards his church, and shewn how far he answers his title, as the Lamb in the midst of the throne, in feeding his church and people, or giving such discoveries unto them as answer the same purpose to the soul as food does to the body.

IT may next be necessary to consider what is meant by His leading them to living fountains of waters. Here our Lord's administration may be taken up in a twofold view: First, with respect to the militant members of his church: And in the second place, with respect to those in the church triumphant.

HIS conduct towards his people, in their mili∣tant state, shall be first considered: And in order to the right understanding of what may be said upon this branch of our Lord's administration, it may be necessary to observe a few things, to open the way for what may be said.

1. IT may be observed that the Almighty, in divine revelation, has exprest his mind anent divine things in such a manner as is suited to our imperfect state and capacity. Leading, and fountains of waters, are terms that the meanest capacity can understand, and point out that there is some analogy between the conduct of Christ, the true shepherd, and shep∣herds among men: For he leads his people like a flock of sheep, and refreshes them with divine con∣solation, as with pure water. There will be no occasion to change scripture expressions for fear of men fixing wrong ideas or notions unto them, since there are but few who literally believe and understand similies. When Christ is said to lead his people into living fountains of waters, few but the prophane will fix a literal meaning to the words. It is true indeed, that a philosopher, or a modern gospeler, would endeavour to avoid these expressions, and shun the phrase, Leading to living fountains of waters, as he would do fire, through the whole of
his discourse: But whoever endeavours to substitute modern diction in religious discourses, especially in sermons, in the room of scripture phrases, will stand a fair chance to be less understood. They may in∣deed please the vain and giddy, and be popular, be∣cause new; and for this very reason they please Sa∣tan too, who hates the plain manner of teaching used in scripture.

THE scriptures themselves are the sword of the spirit, and are most hurtful to the kingdom of Sa∣tan when used in their native simplicity; but when once their doctrines are blunted with men's inven∣tions, like the edge of a sword laid by, they will do little execution.

A MODERN teacher would perhaps say from these words, That Jesus, the best of teachers, has “taught us a perfect system of morals, and left us a pure example; and when we imitate him by observing these rules he hath left us, we advance ”forward in goodness and virtue.

BUT there is as much and more understood by say∣ing, that he leads his people to living fountains of wa∣ters, and as easily comprehended by such as read the scriptures. Such as are only acquainted with plays and romances, will not indeed understand the figures of scripture, nor the meaning of the similies there made use of; but those who read the Bible will, in some measure, understand them. There is a differ∣ence between understanding similies literally, and departing from them; nor do we find the most ig∣norant among ordinary readers of scripture, in great danger of believing them so. The Almighty cer∣tainly knew what was the best method to convey divine truths to the souls of men, and has given us palpable examples in divine revelation.

2. I OBSERVE, that this phrase in the text is a figure taken from the case and custom of travel∣lers in the eastern warm climates, (and seems to be
a Hebrewism) where guides were made use of to direct travellers in their way, and point out unto them the springs and fountains of water that were needful to refresh them in their journey. It teach∣eth us how dependent we are upon our Redeemer, both in this life and that which is to come, for our comfort and true happiness: And that it is upon his powerful grace we must depend for all we need and expect through eternity. As the pilgrim upon his journey depended upon his guide, so must christians depend upon Christ; and as they were directed by their leaders to the fountains and springs of water, by which they were refreshed, and enabled to pursue their jour∣ney, so every true believer shall be directed by Jesus to the promises and means of salvation, necessary to comfort their souls in their state of pilgrimage here below. From such a figure of speech or simile, we can as easily understand the nature of Christ's ad∣ministration, as the leader of his people, as we can learn the meaning of any thing we never saw, by demonstration or description. For unless it is af∣firmed, that there is no analogy between our Lord's administration, and that of a guide to a traveller; and between refreshing fountains, and the means of grace, the instruction from the simile will hold good.

THE teaching by similies has been practised by the wisest of men: Solomon in his book of Proverbs, very often observes this method of teaching. It is not indeed used in argument; for the design of a simile is not to prove what is doubtful, but to clear what is dark. Solomon, very successfully ob∣serves this method, Prov. xxvi. 1. As snow in sum∣mer, and rain in harvest; so honour is not seemly for a fool. Ver. 14. As the door turneth upon its hinges, so doth the slothful upon his bed. Chap. xxviii. 15. As a roaring lion, and a ranging bear; so is a wicked ruler over the poor people. Our Saviour, in his para∣bles,
practised this method often, and the prophets give many instances of this manner of instruction; as in Isa. v. 1. where the church is compared unto a vineyard. Many of the best heathen writers, both poets and others, abound with this kind of metaphor. The most striking passages in sacred writ are of this kind, as Psal. xiv. throughout.

3. THAT it is a character very often given to our mediator in scripture, which the apostle gives him here, viz. a Leader, as in Isa. lv. 4. Behold I have given him for a witness to the people, a leader and commander to the people. Chap. xlviii. 17. Thus saith the Lord thy redeemer, the holy one of Israel, I am the Lord thy God which teacheth thee to profit, which leadeth thee by the way that thou shouldst go. Psal. xxiii. 2. He leadeth me beside the still waters. John x. 3. To him the porter openeth; and the sheep hear his voice; and he calleth his own sheep by name, and leadeth them out. He is said to lead Joseph like a flock, and to bring or lead his people to the borders of his sanctuary. From all this it is plain, that such who read the scriptures cannot be ignorant of this character of Jesus Christ our saviour. Neither will it, I think, be necessary to change the phrase in the subsequent part of this discourse.

4. I OBSERVE, that the gifts and graces of the Holy Spirit, and the ordinances of grace, are very often in divine revelation compared unto waters, wells, and fountains of water. In Psal. xxiii. the blessings of the Holy Spirit are compared to still waters: Thou leadest me beside the still waters. To a river, Ezek. xlvii. 5. And it was a river I could not pass over: For the waters were risen, waters to swim in, a river that could not be passed over. The Holy Spirit that Christ bestowed upon his disciples is compared unto a well of living waters springing up unto eternal life, John iv. 14. And whosoever shall drink of the water that I shall give him, shall never
thirst; but the water that I shall give him, shall be in him a well of living water, springing up unto everlasting life. The means of grace, or the benefits of the covenant of grace, are compared to wells of water; Isa. xii. 3. Therefore with joy shall they draw water out of the wells of salvation. The fountains of living waters in our text, must therefore be understood of the blessing of the covenant of grace, consisting of all the means that the Holy Spirit makes effectual for salvation in this life, and for glory in that which is to come. I shall now proceed to consider our Mediator's conduct towards his people in their mi∣litant state, expressed under the notion of leading them to living fountains of waters.

1. HE makes them sensible of their wants, and leads them into an understanding of their need of spiritual enjoyments. By either his ordinances, or providences, he makes them sensible that their first condition is a miserable one. Sometimes provi∣dence disappoints their hopes, and renders their most sanguine expectations vain: So that what they promised themselves the greatest happiness in the enjoyment of, is quite taken from them, and they have the desire but not the object. The mind that is naturally full of desire, after one disappoint∣ment, turns itself towards some other object, and lives by hope for a season, till providence as before removes the object and eludes the expectation. Still the cry of the heart is, who will shew us any good thing; and the fluctuating mind goes from one temporal object to another in search of happiness and enjoy∣ment, but time after time is disappointed. When these sources fail, the hopeless soul turns serious, engages in a course of religious duties, and seeks comfort in ordinances; and the constant cry now is, the temple of the Lord. But no sooner is a form of godliness established, and the soul begins to place its comfort and happiness in external privi∣leges,
than ordinances are like worldly enjoyments before, delusionary and vain; afford no solid peace nor pleasure. The spirit of bondage shews the spirit of the law, and that the design of duty and the in∣tention of ordinances, are not to be seen of men but to glorify God. Then the man's conduct appears to him in a worse light than before. He imagines, as is the real case with him, that he is a self-de∣ceiver, and a hypocrite; and that by seeking to e∣stablish a righteousness of his own, he is not subject to the righteousness of God. Hence a want of righte∣ousness wherewith he may come before the Lord, mightily perplexes his mind. Sometimes want of sincerity is all the want of righteousness that is yet thought upon.—Then he attempts to be more sincere; strives to bring his mind to a lively and fit frame for devotion, that he may have satisfac∣tion in the exercise of duty, when the end of his pursuit is only for satisfaction to himself, but not to glorify the author of his being. His fear of hy∣pocrisy does not arise so much from an apprehen∣sion that it is dishonouring to God, as that it will provoke him to punish the guilty soul for such so∣lemn dissimulation. But after, by renewed efforts of industry, the man has brought his mind to the conceived measure he would be at, he is ready to conclude he has attained to the desired point of en∣quiry: When behold the mind that never rests in its searches, finds out the error of deficiency in the end. The cause of this is the Lamb in the midst of the throne, by a new manifestation of the spirit of the law upon the conscience, convincing the person that no action is acceptable that is not directed to a good and holy end. Where to find out a mean to amend this error is not easily found; for the no∣tion of self-importance is natural to every irregene∣rate person, and to get clear of our own importance in the performance of duty, is above the power of
corrupt nature. The brightness of legal evidence still increases against the sinner; he sees the com∣mandments true and holy, and the sanction sure; but sinds no will or power to love its holiness, nor a way to evade its curse. A want, a miserable want, now occurs to him; a want of power to keep the law of God, without which he cannot learn how God will be pleased with him. He had already tried to observe the Divine commandments, but found himself far short in both end and motive. Will God accept of another attempt to serve him better, with more sincerity, with a view to his glory? is again suggested, but not so easily concluded upon.

A NOTION of repentance for former sins, and sorrow for past faults and offences, is now deter∣mined, and the man is now all humility, prayer and tears.—This course is pleasing for a season, and the sinner is now busy in making an atonement to God for his former sins and insincerity. But as it is natural for our minds to enquire into future conse∣quences, this laborious penitent cannot long con∣tinue in this course, without enquiring what will be the end, and for what use this repentance is. One thing was neglected at the beginning, which creates more sorrow and trouble in the end: Will God accept of this my repentance for an atonement for my former offences? This is a question that the conscience cannot be long in suspense about, so soon as it looks to God's holy law: For repentance, be it never so sincere, cannot make atonement for sin; because the law of God is infinitely perfect, and the sinner's repentance is but finite.—Besides repen∣tance is nothing, if it is not attended with con∣stancy and uniformity in good actions: And one capital defect in this repentance is, that original sin is not the object of it. Had the man seen the nature of original sin, he would never attempted to
please God by repentance, because this root of bit∣terness will marr the success of repentance itself.— For it is impossible for one to repent sincerely, when there is a propensity in their nature against the ve∣ry duty.

NOW, and never till now, did he see the want of original righteousness. The guilt of Adam's first sin, and the corruption of nature, now marr all his hopes of ever reconciling himself to God; besides, he also sees innumerable imperfections in his most sincere attempts.—What shall I do to be saved? is a very important question, but how to answer it he is unable.—With help he thinks this may be done, but where to find help he knows not. He fears now so much as to look at the law; but conscience having already got the impressions of it stamped there, with all the poison of the curse, there is no getting free of it.—Thus he is a magor misibib, a terror to himself. Fears of death now haunt him like a ghost: To die in this condition is really dan∣gerous, and scarcely more so than he apprehends it. A view of the Lamb in the midst of the throne would be a very acceptable perception, but this in wisdom is yet withheld.—He sees a throne of judgment, but not of mercy. The conclusion is that he must perish for all he hath yet seen. The Lamb in the midst of the throne has all this while been leading him, but in such a manner as Moses led Israel through the wilderness; where there were many things fearful to behold. This pre∣pares him for the enjoyment of the living waters that he leads him afterwards into. In such ways does Jesus sometimes lead his people, when he brings them to the fountains of living water. This makes them sensible of their wants, and makes the Divine goodness relish sweetly when it is enjoyed.— Now the soul is sensible of a want of righteousness to justify it, and a want of meetness to make it fit
for communion with God. We have observed that ordinances and providences are made use of to make men sensible of their wants.—The word strips the sinner, thus convinced, naked of all de∣fence in himself, and makes him see that all his for∣mer attempts to cover himself with his fig-leaves are vain; when the commandment comes powerfully, sin revives and the man dies.

2. HE makes known to them his own excel∣lencies and fitness to reconcile them unto God. Nothing can be more agreeable and desirable to a mind under a sense of apprehended wrath and judg∣ment, than the discovery of one who is able and willing to save. The gospel of the grace of God reveals that object. The Lamb in the midst of the throne brings the glad tidings of peace and great joy to the sinner's ear, and gives the favourable inti∣mation, that he is made of God, wisdom, righteousness, sanctification and redemption. The soul, we observed before, was made sensible of its want of righteous∣ness for acceptance before God. The Redeemer in the gospel says, Behold I bring near my righteous∣ness, and my salvation shall not tarry. The appre∣hension of this righteousness, when revealed, is yet beyond the reach of a natural man; and the wisdom and goodness of Christ is abundantly manifested in leading his people forward to a dependence upon him, for power to apply his righteousness, as well as to depend upon him for working it out.

WHEN men are brought to a sense of their absolute misery, without Christ, and made sensible of their own weakness, it is ordinary to tell them they should embrace him; but could they do this, it would be doing more than even keeping the law perfectly. This is as impossible to that soul that is not changed, as any former duty mentioned. The Lamb in the midst of the throne must work this work himself; namely, work the power by which
they apprehend him. They must be first appre∣hended of him, before they can apprehend him: This is the language of the apostle Paul, I endea∣vour to apprehend him, of whom I am also apprehended. The first is an endeavour that flows from the latter. The word of Jesus is sent with power to the soul in a more direct manner, and gives strength to it to believe, before there can be any special embra∣cing of him as our Lord. Our appropriating of Christ to ourselves, or that special particular faith, which is the privilege of the children of God, is no more but the love of God working in the conscience, and expressing itself by embracing an object it de∣lights in. I indeed sincerely allow of an appropri∣ating faith; but refuse that all the exhortations in the world can effect it; or if it were done in obe∣dience to the commandment and exhortation, could it justify us, otherwise we would be justified by a work of the law.

BOTH the ground and means of our justification are without us, as they are duties: Both are the work of the Lamb in the midst of the throne. None of the scripture commandments to believe, are to be understood as having the promise of justifica∣tion and salvation connected with them, (as these duties are done by us); otherwise our justification would still depend upon ourselves. For when it is said, Believe in the Lord Jesus Christ and thou shalt be saved; it no doubt implies, that faith is our du∣ty, but will not infer that we can obey it till it be given us. These words shew the necessity of faith, but do not mention the cause of it. It is not of ourselves, it is the gift of God: In that phrase we may see the connection between faith and salvation, but cannot learn that faith is an act that we can put forth when we please. The Divine order of faith, but not the Divine cause, is there mentioned. The apostles point out the method of salvation to the
jailot, without mentioning unto him the powerful cause, that only could make him comply with that method.

THE Lamb in the midst of the throne presents to the soul, in the day of believing, his own righte∣ousness and excellencies, and impresses their fitness so powerfully upon the mind, that it makes way into the heart by melting it. Thus the soul re∣ceives a new form by the power of Divine grace: The evidence of the fitness and goodness of the Redeemer's excellencies for holiness and happiness, makes way into the soul, and changes it as a clear and convincing truth will change one's sentiments, and form their thoughts into a liking for that truth. Our Lord Jesus Christ, when he leads his people into the understanding of his own fitness and ex∣cellency, performs a work that no human energy could effect, no persuasion of men produce. All that men can say of him, without the special power of his grace, will make but small impression upon the soul. There is a more direct impulse necessary. The excellencies of Jesus, set forth by human com∣mendation, are like the rays of the sun dissipated and scattered; but when impressed by his own more immediate power, are like the rays of the sun con∣tracted into a meniscus or burning glass, that burns as well as gives light. This is expressed by the apostle, The light of the glory of God in the face of Jesus shining into the soul. This is a peculiar and special part of Christ's divine administration in lead∣ing his people. By this he leads them out of them∣selves to a dependence upon him; and as the love∣liness of his character begets love in their souls, that which is truly called appropriation, is the love of Christ in the soul making free with its object. This is an effect of that faith whereby men are justified. Faith is the gift of God, and the appro∣priation of faith is this Divine gift improving or
making use of its object. Faith takes hold of the testimony where a Saviour is held forth; but the evidence of the truth of the testimony is first made to shine upon the soul. The light of the glory of God in the face of Jesus shines into the darkened understand∣ing, and represents Jesus Christ to the mind in all his fitness and loveliness. The evidence of the truth of his person and character, determines the soul to rest upon him for salvation. Thus the ap∣propriation follows, not precedes an interest in Christ. Our acceptance with God is not founded upon our appropriation of Christ, but upon his atonement, which is the meritorious cause of that grace which enables us to believe in him.

THIS administration of the Son of God, in leading his people to himself, is full of the greatest wisdom: For unless he drew them, they neither would nor could apprehend him. Therefore he first apprehends them by his spirit; writes the truth in their hearts, and they become his. They are justified before God, and accepted of by him, not because they have received Jesus Christ their Lord, but because he hath taken them into a relation to him as their surety. The whole ground of our ac∣ceptance is what Christ hath done, both to us and for us, and not what we ourselves have done in any degree. The believing of the Divine record, in which Christ is comprehended, is the most rational act the soul can put forth; but it is an act that does not proceed from any natural power that is in the mind, till it be given it by Jesus. The power of the word first overcomes the enmity, by represent∣ing a worthy object, before there be any love or de∣sire in the soul towards a Saviour; Jesus in all his lovely excellencies is brought near in a word of truth, and this like a seal is imprinted upon the soul, and gives it a new form. It is the soul thus formed new that applies Jesus for comfort, as contained in the tes∣timony
of the word. But this after-comfort, is only an effect of the principle of faith before implanted by the spirit of the gospel, or is faith working by love. It is a confounding of justification with a work of sanctification, to affirm that men must ap∣propriate Christ to themselves before they can be justified, or making our sanctification the ground and reason of our acceptance with God: For it is certain whoever is able to receive Christ, must have power, and that power must be given them, which is no more but enabling the soul to act according to the word of God. Therefore it follows from this, that men are accepted not on the account of Christ's atonement, but on the account of the work of the Spirit in sanctification; whereas the aposto∣lic doctrine runs, whom he justifies, them he also sanc∣tifies. The Divine connection observed in the con∣duct of Jesus Christ, in saving his people, and lead∣ing them to everlasting happiness, is worthy of our most serious attention. When sinners are justified, they are said to be justified by the redemption that is in Jesus; by having an interest therein: This in∣terest they obtain by faith: This faith they have by free gift, and not of themselves: So when faith accepts of the atonement for justification, it is no more but the spirit of Jesus enabling the soul to observe the connection established in the covenant of grace. Here is no foundation for human pride or boasting, since the power by which this connec∣tion is observed, is not men's own, but the gift of God working in their conscience, or the love of Christ constraining the soul to receive the atonement.

IT is still evident that our justification, both as to cause, and immediate means, as to beginning and end, is the work of the Lamb in the midst of the throne. That faith that is established in the con∣nection of means in the covenant of grace, without which we cannot be justified, is wrought in the soul
by the power of God. The apostle tells us, He works in us the work of faith with power. When Christ makes known his own excellencies and fit∣ness to the souls of his people, like a true loadstone he draws out their love to him, and brings them near; the love of Christ constrains them: So their acts of faith and love, are only effects of that constraining love of Christ impressed upon the soul. These acts of faith that are so often mentioned in some treatises, and required of men before they be justified, are ra∣tionally accounted for; only, by rightly understand∣ing the administration of Christ, as the Lamb in the midst of the throne who leads his people. The ap∣propriation of Christ for salvation, is just the same thing with do and live, unless we understand this as the effect of his own power in his new covenant admi∣nistration. Before ever a fallen sinner can accept of Jesus Christ for justification, the Redeemer must first take possession of the heart, and by the glory of his divine excellencies captivate the soul. This is an act of his kingly power whereby he subdues the soul to the obedience of faith.

THE Lamb in the midst of the throne leads his people to himself, by such a glorious display of his excellencies and fitness to reconcile them unto God, that the evidence that attends this display of his glory, captivates the heart, and fills the whole soul with love.

3. THE Lamb in the midst of the throne leads his militant members through many trials and afflic∣tions after they become his. Jesus Christ told his disciples, that such as followed him, must also take up their cross, and deny themselves. It is the constant doc∣trine of the New Testament, that them that live god∣ly in this world shall suffer persecution. By afflic∣tions and trials in this life, the followers of the Lamb are made meet for that which is to come. Jesus leads all his followers in the same path that he himself
walked in; and as the captain of their salvation was made perfect through sufferings, so must all those who are his sincere followers. The followers of the Lamb are best known by their resignation to suffering and self-denial. When men are followers of religion, when every advantage attend-it, the lovers of the world, and the lovers of Christ are not easily dis∣tinguished. That religion that has no cross attend∣ing it, bears not the marks of the apostolic reli∣gion: For the apostle Paul says of himself, that bonds and persecution awaited him in every place. The cross of Christ is intended for his people's very great ad∣vantage: To keep them in constant dependence up∣on him, and to stain the pride of all human glory. By these two the primitive christians were distinguished from the world; namely, the patient bearing of the cross, and denying themselves. They rejoiced that they were counted worthy to suffer shame for the name of Jesus Christ; and denied themselves the ease and carnal pleasure, that was obtained by compliance with the world. Their esteem of religion proceed∣ed from their love to its author, and not from these appendages that worldly men afterwards connected with it. Had they had an inclination to have en∣joyed the advantages that afterwards many connec∣ted with christianity, they might no doubt have had their own share; but they were sensible that this was incompatible with what Jesus had told them, of the cross and self-denial. The many suf∣ferings these first christians were exposed unto, arose from their non-conformity to the reigning customs; and it was a special evidence of their self-denial, when they could for the sake of pure and undefiled religion forego the smiles of the world, and the allure∣ments of pre-eminence, wealth, and esteem. It is the certain way to the crown of everlasting life, to walk in the way of self-denial and afflictions. The Lamb in the midst of the throne never led his people
in any other path. Tho' religion, falsly so called, has had its own time of reigning under the protec∣tion of civil power, yet Christ's kingdom never was of this world. Those reigning systems that were attended with worldly advantages, power, and pre-eminence, were palpable deviations from the apos∣tolic system. Christ never intended power and preference as the privilege of his followers; but assured them that they should be hated of all men for his name's sake, which was a part of the cross they were to bear.—And instead of accepting places of power and advancement, they were to deny them∣selves to these allurements, as pertaining to the king∣doms of this world, of which they were to be civil subjects, but never religious rulers or lords.

THE followers of the Lamb must not think when they become his, that then the smiles of providence, and the approbation of every devotee to the name of christianity, will be their privilege: The contrary they must expect. If they become true children of God thro' Jesus Christ, false brethren, mothers, chil∣dren, will hate them. This is often the heaviest branch of the christian's cross, to be despised and hated by those who have as high pretensions to religion as themselves. An instance of this we have in the case of David, Ps. xlii. 3. My tears have been my meat day and night, while they continually say unto me, Where is thy God? When I remember these things, I pour out my soul in me; for I had gone with the multitude, I went with them into the house of God. Self-denial has always been accounted, as it really is, a singula∣rity in religion. Such as join the notions of chris∣tianity and worldly esteem and advantage together, have ever since the reign of Tiberius looked upon self-denial and the cross of Christ with an evil eye.

THE excellent few who could not be conformed to the world, because their consciences would not allow them, and their love to Jesus Christ directed
them otherwise, have been looked upon as foolish sticklers for unnecessary singularities. The men who loved to model the kingdom of Jesus into the form of the kingdoms of this world, have al∣ways esteemed the plain simple followers of Jesus Christ as conscientious fools, who would not lay down the cross of Christ when better offers were made them. It was the Lamb in the midst of the throne that kept them from embracing a religion that was not his, but a creature of worldly power, and led them through all the reproaches of such as called themselves by the magnificent name of the CHRISTIAN WORLD.

WHEN men are truly converted to the religion of Jesus Christ, they are deceived if they expect that he will lead them in the way of worldly e∣steem: They must follow the footsteps of his flock, and go forth without the camp, bearing reproach for the name of Christ; and with the apostle, count all things but loss and dung, that they may win Christ, and be found in him, not having their own righteousness which is of the law, but that which is of God by faith.

THIS branch of the Redeemer's administration, is that whereby he keeps up the distinction between his children and the children of this world. Self-denial is the truest mark of a follower of Christ; for it is directly opposite to that notion of self-im∣portance and dependence, that is the leading prin∣ciple of the self-righteous of every character: It is the hardest lesson in the whole christian scheme for men to learn. There are very many who pre∣tend to follow Jesus Christ, that are like the woman mentioned in Isa. iv. 1. who want only to be called by his name, but love to support the notion of their own independence; these have a name to live, but are really dead. The true sincere followers of the Lamb are led to depend upon him for all things; for wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption.

THOSE whom the Lamb leadeth are denied to their highest attainments, and only depend upon that first grace which distinguished them from the world. Their right to happiness, and their walk∣ing in peace, they attribute to that unchangeable word that passeth not away, which first gave them life, and still supports them in it. The religious, or rather the superstitious world, who are power∣fully governed by the notion of independence, ge∣nerally lay a mightly stress upon their attainments, and reckon themselves intitled to a higher degree of the favour of the Deity than others, because they can give a better account of their attainments, and lay a greater weight upon what they call experien∣ces, than upon that invariable testimony which contains the substance of both their happiness and the ground of their faith. They are so far from denying themselves, that, the higher their notions of their own attainments are, they are the more proud. This is evidenced from their sovereign contempt of others, who cannot say that they have gone through the same exercise with them. The followers of the Lamb, in the apostolic times, who were led by him, founded their esteem of themselves and others upon that one profession of faith in Jesus, and the similitude of the tenor of their lives to that profes∣sion. Their love was founded upon that which was visible to every one, namely, their profession of their faith in Christ, and the working thereof by love; and not upon what no man can see so as to be certain of. Whoever adhered unto the same testimony of truth, which was visible without them, and lived according to its purity, were the objects of their esteem.

THEY did not set up their own attainments and experiences as the standard to others, and the rule of their love and esteem of them; but the Divine testimony which Jesus had left them. They
loved those who loved Jesus Christ, and evidenced their love by embracing his true religion. The whole rule of their love of others was without them, not within them. They left men's hearts to him who searcheth the hearts of the sons of men, and lived only from external evidence. Their love was ca∣tholic and universal towards all who profest the common faith of christians, so long as they conti∣nued in obedience to that faith; but they extended not their esteem to any, differing from them in the faith of Jesus Christ, whatever pretensions they had to attainments and experience in religion. As they acknowledged but one Lord, so they had but one faith which wrought by love to all who profest it.

THESE primitive followers of the Lamb, were solely directed in all their actions by those rules their Lord and Saviour had given them. They denied themselves to dependence upon human pre∣tensions or inventions. The sure word of prophecy, was the foundation to them of the exercise of every christian grace or virtue. Modern times have pro∣duced a christian world, but the primitive christians always kept themselves distinct from the world, and looked upon the world and christianity as having separate interests.

THE account that christians could give of their adherence to the faith of Jesus in the gospel, and not an account of so many convictions and round∣about workings of the human mind, was the rule they judged of men by. The Lamb in the midst of the throne taught them to deny all these, as a part of that selfish disposition that sets itself in opposition to the gospel. Jesus Christ teaches men to rest upon the word, as the true ground of hope, faith, and assurance; but to rest upon no man's account of his own frame and disposition. Our Lord Jesus Christ himself never required of any to believe in him for his inward frame and disposition, but on
account of his works: If I do not the works which no other man can do, believe me not.

IT is an eminent degree of self-denial, to have no dependence upon these things which to us may seem our best and most spiritual actions or exer∣cises. The great leader of the New Testament, leads all his sincere followers to depend upon him for all things, in opposition unto our own best en∣deavours and performances. This to many will appear no small affliction and trial, and certainly is an high degree of self-denial; but the Lamb in the midst of the throne will bring his people out of all such affliction at last.

HOWEVER unfavourable like the cross of Christ may appear to worldly men, and however unreason∣able self-denial may seem to the devotees of inde∣pendence, yet according to the New Testament none are the followers of the Lamb, but such as take up their cross and deny themselves. The world ever thought the bearing of the cross and self-denial disagreeable lessons to learn. That self-esteem and love to wealth and pre-eminence, that is so natural to the men of this world, will always resist men's inclinations to bear the cross and deny themselves. Those that were the leaders of the fashion in the primitive times, like those who are their successors still, were no doubt surprised to see men sell their possessions, and distribute them for the supply of needy christians. Such a mark of self-denial was no doubt then, as it still is, an eminent piece of foolish sin∣gularity in the eyes of the wise men of this world. The followers of Jesus Christ had their affections set upon things that are above, and could the more easily part with those things that are below. Yet for men to part with possessions, houses and lands, wives and children, for the sake of religion, and be ac∣counted fools for it after all, was such a degree of self denial that the primitive periods only produced.
The Lamb in the midst of the throne enabled his con∣fessors and followers to despise these temporal things, by filling their souls with the comfort of the Holy Ghost. He led them to living fountains of wa∣ters, made them receive the Holy Ghost, which so filled their souls with joy and delight, that they thought little of all worldly advantages and esteem.

THE Divine joy and comfort with which their souls were filled, wrought so powerfully in their minds, that their cross seemed light and easy, and self-denial and suffering was to them rather a crown of rejoicing, than burdensome and grievous. Then christians understood religion in its own native light, as distinct from the world, and had no am∣bition for what they were persuaded was never de∣signed them. The life of Jesus Christ they made choice of for their pattern, who in all his life-time in this world kept himself distinct from its manners, pleasures, and allurements; who said of himself, The foxes have holes, and the birds of the air have nests; but the son of man hath not where to lay his head. So long as christians followed him, they were like him, in denying themselves these pleasures and ad∣vantages that belong only to the world. But after men began to vary from the example of Christ, the question that was once in agitation amongst the disciples, who should be greatest? became the chief enquiry of those called christians.—And now instead of following the Lamb, in bearing the cross, and deny∣ing themselves, men professing his religion contend∣ed with the powers of the world for power and pre∣ference: Till at last the christian religion became so like the world that they interchanged names, and christianity got the new appellation of the CHRISTIAN WORLD.

BUT whatever trials and afflictions may arise to the follower of Jesus Christ, from the want of these temporal things, the Lamb in the midst of the throne
leads them thro' these difficulties, and by the com∣forts of the Holy Spirit, these fountains of living waters make up the want of all these left-hand blessings. By electing them into the secrets of his covenant, and supporting them with the sweets of the promises, he leads them on to the borders of his sanctuary, to the tabernacle that his own right-hand hath pitched for them in his kingdom of glory.

4. ANOTHER branch of Christ's administration as the Lamb in the midst of the throne towards his church in her militant state is, that he leads his peo∣ple through death. We have abundant evidence that death is the common lot of mankind from a long and striking experience of good and bad:— The wise man dieth, and the brutish also:—And Job tells us, that there is an appointed time for man upon earth:—And the apostle, it is appointed for all men once to die, and after that the judgment: But why good men should die, for whom the Son of God laid down his life, seems not so easy to be accounted for. Should I affirm that sincere believers in Jesus Christ do not die, if we understand death in its proper meaning, it will perhaps be nearest the doctrine of the New Testament. The Lamb in the midst of the throne who died for them, only leads them through death. It is only like a stage in their journey, which they must pass thro', but do not abide in. The a∣postle, 1 Thess. iv. 14. compares death to a sleep, so far as it extends to believers:—Them also who sleep in Jesus will God bring with him: The prophet Isaiah compares it to a place of rest:—They shall rest in their beds, each one walking in his uprightness. This change of believers, takes the name of death from its common likeness to the death of others, and hath received the common denomination from its common external appearance. But in truth, is only like the beginning of life to the followers of the Lamb. The living fountains of waters which the
Lamb leads his followers into, makes them live for ever. The leader himself says to his disciples, He that drinketh of the waters that I shall give him, shall not die. The Psalmist compares death only to a shadow that he was to pass through: When I pass through the valley and shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me, thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.

THE reason why the followers of the Lamb die is, that they may be true followers of him, and be exalted from the same low degree of humiliation. He leads them through death, that they may see all the excellencies of his death and sufferings; that they may behold that which is most formidable to human nature in the most intimate manner, and see that it is by the death of Jesus divested of its sting. Every true christian, by passing through death, sees experimentally that Jesus hath overcome it; and what they were by faith persuaded of before, they now sensibly experience The Lamb leads them thro' death that they may be sharers of that victory which he obtained over it, and really find that it has no power. By leading them through death, he gives them occasion to triumph with the apostle, O death where is thy sting! O grave where is thy victory!

WERE christians transported to heaven with∣out going thro' death, it would be a great disad∣vantage to them: For they could not know by ex∣perience that what is so frightful to human nature, is by the death of Jesus made so easy, and conse∣quently there would be a defect in their experience. Death to the followers of Jesus is not an immediate effect of the curse, but a part of that conformity to their Saviour which they attain unto by following him.—Thus it is a privilege, not a disadvantage. The apostle informs us, that death possed upon all men, for all had sinned; but this refers unto the sen∣tence
of condemnation that was upon all men on account of their being descendents of the first Adam under the curse of the law.—But the followers of the Lamb are freed from condemnation, on the account of his being made a curse for them:—And there is no condemnation to them that are in Christ Jesus.—Therefore death to them does not flow from the curse of the law; nor do they die so much because they have sinned, but because it is a part of their conformity to Jesus, to walk in the same path that he walked in.

THAT christians may have a true experience how easy the way to heaven and happiness is, on the account of Jesus Christ having gone before them in it, they must follow him thro' every stage or the way, that they may admire him in all that he hath done. The Lamb leads his followers thro' death, not from any necessity arising from death's claim upon them; but that he may change their vile bodies, and as it were leave their fleshly garments in the ward∣robe of the grave, to be raised up new shining rai∣ments at the resurrection of the just. Jesus Christ leads his people thro' death, that they may see all that it can do unto them, and receive from them all that is its own. Nothing that pertains to a chris∣tian belongs to death, but their earthly house of this tabernacle, which it only can dissolve, but not de∣stroy; for there is nothing about the christian that is properly his that can die.—Even his body which is laid in the grave does not die (if we speak pro∣perly) but rests. By passing thro' death, the follow∣er of the Lamb sees the whole of its power, and its design to him. It as it were catches all his gar∣ments but cannot touch himself.

WHAT may properly be termed the believer's self, passes through death untouched, and his body which he leaves behind him rests in peace, but is not detained like a prisoner. When he passes through
death he sees the advantage of the death of Jesus, that hath destroyed that enemy, and taken away its sting. The Lamb in the midst of the throne in this part of his administration, lets his children see how perfectly he hath freed them from the curse; that no part of the threatning of the law can hurt them. Death was the threatning denounced against men for sin, but now they see that there is no danger in it to them that are in Christ Jesus. It is only the shadow of death to them. Now they go through it in triumph, saying, O death where is thy sting! O grave where is thy victory! The sting of death is sin, and the strength of sin is the law; but thanks be to God who hath given us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
I PROCEED now to consider the administra∣tion of the Lamb in the midst of the throne to∣wards his church and people, in their trium∣phant state in the kingdom of glory.

1. THE Lamb in the midst of the throne sets them free from all the causes and effects of sin and sorrow. The very being of sin being now removed, there is no such bitter exercise as repentance and sorrow for sin.—No fears haunt these regions of bliss, be∣cause no vestiges of sin remain, nor can enter there: No apprehensions of Divine anger are there, be∣cause the love and favour of God doth for ever shine upon that happy society. The light of the Divine countenance that shines for ever bright in these happy mansions excludes all darkness, doubts, and perplexities. Every evil cause is now remo∣ved, and no bad effects are either feared or felt in the new Jerusalem. The seeds and principles of woe and sorrow are now totally removed, and no bitter fruits of contrition and compunction for sin, are ever experienced in heaven.

JESUS CHRIST their Lord, gives them the full sense of true liberty. Their consciences that before, in
their best condition, were liable to be impressed with apprehensions of wrath for sin and short-coming, and to be stained with guilt, have now the fullest sense of assured bliss.

THEIR liberty consists now in being freed from all fear: For the perfection of love casts it all out. They have also the fullest desires to serve God and the Lamb: The apostle tells us they rest not day nor night, but sing hallelujahs to him that sits upon the throne and to the Lamb for ever and ever.

THESE living fountains of waters that overflow in heaven, these glorious outlettings of Divine love fill the souls of the followers of the Lamb with a sweet sense of Divine liberty; a sense of guilt, or ap∣prehensions of Divine anger, or fears of tempta∣tions overcoming virtue, make the christian even in his best state, not to serve with that liberty he will do when all these are removed. In heaven believers experience the truest and fullest sense of liberty: They feel their consciences disentangled from all apprehensions of either sinning or suf∣fering.

2. HE leads them to the most full and intimate communion with God. Jesus Christ presents his followers before God without spot or wrinkle, or any such thing: And leads them into such an immediate knowledge and acquaintance with the Deity, as supersedes the necessity of enquiry into his charac∣ter by means as formerly.—This is expressed by the apostle by the emphatic phrase of, seeing face to face, and knowing as we are known. That com∣munion which men enjoy with God in this life con∣sists in the knowing and understanding his charac∣ter by the means he hath appointed.—It is like a communion kept up by distant correspondence, in a testimony brought near by messengers, where the amiable character of Jehovah is so lively drawn that it affects the heart, and begets a similitude of
sentiment.—But the communion that the Lamb leads his followers into, resembles personal acquaint∣ance, where all the charms of immediate vision and fruition are enjoyed. The God of love now shines forth in the radiance of his lovely nature to the souls of beings made meet to enjoy his endeared embraces.

THE scripture sets forth this blessed communion in a bold and striking view; as beholding the light of the Divine countenance; reigning for ever and ever with him; eating and drinking in his presence: All which point out the most full and intimate fellow∣ship. They do not now view God through the lattice of ordinances in an imperfect manner: They see the very brightness of his countenance. They have the most intimate knowledge of him; for they see him as he is, and love him according to that understanding they have of him, which is perfect. The whole capacity of their soul is filled with the blessed discoveries they have of the Deity. When we consider that all infirmities are now removed, all prejudices rooted out of the soul, and add to this that the object of all true joy and delight is repre∣sented without any dark shadows or intervening means, the communion must be most full and com∣prehensive.

OUR conceptions of this communion in this life are but very faint and inadequate, and we would have had no just views of what it is in a future state at all, if it had not been revealed unto us; but from the New Testament description of it we may gather that it will far transcend our present notions of it. When we conceive of an immediate intercourse with God, we are obliged to subtract from our conceptions every imperfection which at∣tend human intercourse, and leave room for some∣thing yet unknown. For the apostle tells us, that eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither hath it entered
into the heart of man to conceive what God hath laid up for them who fear him. There will, no doubt, in another life be discoveries made to the saints, as much above their present comprehension, as that state is above the present.

3. HE affords them the most pure and successive joy arising from the sense of this communion. What before they only had a right unto, they now have a full enjoyment of, and they are now admitted to drink of the fountain of life, of the rivers of pleasure at God's right-hand. In their militant state, christi∣ans are often in heaviness through manifold tempta∣tions; their joy is frequently intermitted; but in that state of perfection, their hope is perfect, and the truest and fullest sense of a present and lasting enjoyment of the highest good, affords the most pure and constant joy. The Psalmist expresses the spring of this joy under the notion of a pure foun∣tain, Psal. xxvi. 9. that is free of all mixture. And as the cause of this joy is eternally the same, so it is constant and successive. That glorious object that gave them sometimes such delight and satisfaction at a distance, will no doubt fill their souls with ex∣ceeding great joy, when they are brought so near as to see face to face, as the apostle expresses it. The invariableness of the object, and the refined capa∣city of their soul, will make them fit to enjoy a suc∣cessive fulness of joy. The very suitableness of the object to the mind, and its being capable to enjoy it, must create a constant pleasure. The sweetness of that communion, and the fulness of it, must create a constant satisfaction. Its sweetness creates delight, and its fulness and permanency make it lasting.

THE Lamb in the midst of the throne is the con∣stant medium through which everlasting joy flows to every one of his redeemed children; and by bringing them to that state where the Divine glory
shines most remarkably through, or in his face, he for ever solaces them with a complete vision and fruition of the highest good. This joy flows from the constant excellency and beauty they behold shining in the face of Jesus, which they are admitted to see for ever through eternity. The Psalmist ex∣presseth this joy, and the cause of it, in strong and emphatical language, Psal. xvi. 11. In thy presence is fulness of joy, and at thy right-hand are pleasures for evermore.—This bliss and happiness is attributed to Jesus Christ as the author of it, as all men's views of God in heaven will constantly, will for ever, be thro' him; and our everlasting peace with God will come thro' our Lord Jesus Christ. No other views will men have of God, but such as come through his well-beloved Son. This blessed communion, in which all their happiness consists, affords the most pure and refined joy in a continued succession of raptures: The more of God they behold, the far∣ther they see into the nature and extent of his Di∣vine perfections: The more of his love and grace they understand, the fuller will their joy be. Joy is the triumph of the soul, or the way that it ex∣presses its love and delight in the object it loves. When Jesus reveals the wonderful depths of the love of Jehovah to the glorified hosts above, the scene is so engaging, the sight so attracting, and withal the glory of the Divine love so filling and satisfying to a glorified soul, that it cannot but be ravished with the discovery. It even overcame the apostle Paul in this present world, when he began to contemplate the depths thereof, it led him out into a transport of joy; O the height! and depth! the length! and breadth of the love of God! it passeth all finding out. If such a partial communion and enjoyment in a militant state, threw Paul into such raptures, what must the overflowing depths above, in the ocean of bliss, do to those whom the Lamb
in the midst of the throne leads into all the ravishing discoveries of Divine fulness of love, grace and mercy. It is the successive joy arising from the continued communion with God, that fills their mouths with constant praises, and their tongues with songs of everlasting joy. If we consider Jesus Christ as an active Being, a person in the same activity of character as when he was in this world, we must no doubt conceive him still engaged in doing his Father's business. As it was his busi∣ness while here to shew the Father to his followers and disciples, we must not think but when he brings them to heaven, but he will still more fully discover him unto them. Heaven is certainly a place of ac∣tion, tho' the Divine employment there is an ever∣lasting rest, as none of the inhabitants are wearied with their labour. The Lamb in the midst of the throne performs an active part in that happy situa∣tion, and leads his people into still more full fountains of joy.

4. THE Lamb in the midst of the throne wipes away all their reproaches that have been unjustly cast upon them. In this present life reproaches, like tears to a fair countenance, may darken a fair character; may make innocence appear as it were in her mourning robes. David says, reproach had near broke his heart. Tho' an innocent person may comfort himself under reproach, that he is innocent, yet it is often to him that others are imposed upon, and his usefulness in a great measure marred. Tho' integrity will stand the test and come off victorious, yet it often happens that a man's usefulness is hin∣dered by means of these unjust reproaches.

IN heaven these reproaches are wiped away, and innocence made to appear in all its fair and beauti∣ful charms. As the Almighty puts the tears of his people in his bottle, as the Psalmist expresseth it, and remembers his children's reproaches, so at last he
will wipe them away, to their everlasting vindica∣tion and eternal comfort. The scandalous tongue, that like a poisoned arrow fixed in the reputation of the innocent, shall be wrapt up in flames of fire, and the patient sufferer set free from its scandal. That obliquy that bore hard upon them in this life, God shall throw into the bottomless pit, and every piece of unjust scandal into the lake that burns with fire and brimstone. These vipers that fixt in the cha∣racter of the saints, like that which fixt upon Paul's hand, shall be shaken off into everlasting fire; yea these temptations that Satan hath often laid before the people of God, and urged their compliance with, and tempted them again to believe they did yield, shall all of them be removed from their ac∣count, and added to his own crimes. Evey blot shall be wiped from their character, and they shall appear before God without spot or wrinkle, or any such thing.
THE last thing in the method was to make some improvement.

1. WE may learn that all the titles of Jesus Christ are full of true signification. He is called the Lamb in the midst of the throne, and the answers his title exactly. He was a spotless sin-offering, holy, harmless, undefiled, and separate from sinners; without guile, nor was sin found in his mouth. In this character he bore the punishment of our sin; and as the Paschal Lamb was a sacrifice, whose blood saved the Israelites from temporal judgments, so the blood of the Lamb of God takes away the sin of the world, and delivers believers from spiritual and eternal death.—This title carries more in it than mere al∣lusion; it also denotes his real fitness to save his peo∣ple from their sins: It shews what character he bore when here, and still sustains in his exalted state. It shews that there was a real translation of guilt upon him: This John intimates when he says, Be∣hold
the Lamb of God, that taketh away the sin of the world! I know that some who have gained the ap∣probation and attention of the fashionable world, alledge that guilt is personal, and cannot be im∣puted to the innocent, and that vicarious punish∣ment or atonement, is contrary to the goodness of God, which cannot make innocence suffer: But as these of that persuasion form a character to the De∣ity after their own imagination, which is not to be found in scripture; and conceive what he should be, but do not hold by his own description of his cha∣racter, it is no wonder the death of Jesus Christ as an atonement is foolishness to them. Nothing is more evident from the scripture, than the notion of vi∣carious punishment:—He bore our sins on his own body on the tree:—He was made sin for us, who knew no sin, that we might be made the righteousness of God in him. We are not obliged to account to these monopolizers of reason, why the Deity made Jesus Christ sin, or made him suffer for our sins; but on∣ly reply, that the whole scripture is full of this doc∣trine, and if it is wrong, they know whom to chal∣lenge. Were there not a true significancy in this title of Jesus Christ, all the Old Testament saints have been in a great error, by trusting to unsigni∣ficant types; and the apostle Paul does not seem to have understood them right, when he says, that all the fathers passed under the cloud, and they all passed through the sea; that they all eat the same spiritual meat, and did all drink the same spiritual drink: For they drank of the rock that followed them, and that rock was Christ. Jesus Christ answers his type not merely for the sake of form, but for the end of salvation:— That both the Old and New Testament saints might be freed from the curse of the law, and that a sure ground of hope might be laid for all future believers.

WITHOUT considering Jesus as the slain Lamb of God, and the atonement for our sins, there can be no
relief for a guilty conscience severely prest with e∣very reason of despair. Every sense of guilt and imperfection will press hard upon the mind, and every view of the Divine character in its purity and perfection, will enforce the reasons of despair, till the soul either totally despond, or seek a refuge in future non-existence.

IT is only a firm persuasion of the truth of Christ's propitiation as the Lamb of God, with which the De∣ity has declared his satisfaction, that will satisfy the conscience of a sinner in his dying moments. And tho' many who have professed to discredit this truth, and have founded the ground of their ac∣ceptance upon their repentance and sincere endea∣vours, have tried to make a shift to die decently like philosophers and good men; yet notwithstanding, as much often transpires to the world as to shew the deceitfulness of their pretensions, and how weak their hopes of future happiness are.

IF the title of Jesus Christ, as the Lamb in the midst of the throne, has signification, and there be truth in the atonement, then all who trust therein have certainty of eternal life and happiness; but on the other hand, all at best is merely probable, a pure peradventure. God is indeed good, but he bestows his goodness according to the good pleasure of his will: This is the rule of the communication of his goodness and mercy to any. The adversa∣ries of the atonement dare not say that God neces∣sarily bestows his goodness upon his creatures, o∣therwise they cannot deprive devils of their own share; for they are his creatures as well as men. The way of enjoying mercy and goodness from God is only through the atonement of our Lord Jesus Christ. In Jesus, his perfect character shines with resplendent glory: There every attribute of his na∣ture is perfectly illustrated: Mercy and truth meet together, righteousness and peace kiss one another. The
wisdom of men, that is foolishness with God, is ready to raise the laugh and irrefragable smile, at supposing any variance among the Divine attri∣butes; but notwithstanding of their ridicule, and blasphemous laugh, according to God's revealed character exhibited in the scriptures, his attributes cannot agree should he save men without an atone∣ment: And all his dispensations towards men since the beginning of the world, declare that salvation to sinners was always intended through an atone∣ment. Nothing could make this necessary but the honour of the Divine character, and the glory of the attributes of God: For had the Deity intended to make sinners happy at the expence of his truth, justice, and righteousness, there was no need for Jesus Christ at all. And it would be still more un∣accountable, to make a holy innocent person suffer for no reason at all, but mere arbitary pleasure, when neither love to men, nor any necessity from his own character obliged him to it. Religion may here turn the ridicule upon her adversaries, and ask what was the reason that the Deity made Jesus Christ suffer pain and agony of the severest kind, when he had never sinned, nor given the least offence to any:—When he had received the fullest testimony of the Divine approbation twice from the excellent glory: This is my beloved son, in whom I am well pleased. Is not this to set the Divine at∣tributes at variance: To exclude goodness and justice, and represent the Deity as a being possessed of wanton cruelty? Such a character as this, one may justly form to a Nero, a Caligula, or a Domiti∣an, who out of wantonness and arbitrary cruelty, ex∣posed the primitive christians to the severest torture, when they could lay nothing to their charge that was blame-worthy.

To make Jesus Christ suffer such pain and tor∣ture when he had the most evident approbation of
innocence, and had done nothing amiss, is to give such a character of the Deity, as is only consistent with the worst of beings. But when we consider the Lamb of God suffering for the sins of an elect world, that they may enjoy eternal life, and that all the attributes of God may be glorified in their hap∣piness; a consistent character given to the Almigh∣ty: Here noble and excellent ends are proposed, and what otherwise was impossible, is rendered pos∣sible; and what was inconsistent, made agreeable. No objections can be justly brought against the real significancy of our Redeemer's title; pride only finds them out. Human pride only cannot see the need and usefulness of a satisfaction. The a∣tonement of Jesus Christ sets all men on the same footing in point of acceptance with God, which hath produced no little chagrin among the votaries of human excellence, and the devotees of self-de∣pendence. The very great enmity that the world shewed against Jesus Christ, arose from the consider∣ation that his life and doctrine, death and sufferings, were a check upon the pride of men, and designed to stain the pride of all glory. The proud and haughty Jews were offended at the meek and low∣ly Jesus, because he judged them to hell for their haughtiness and pride. They understood his cha∣racter a little, but did not love it: It was so far as they understood it, they hated him. They found he was designed to put all men upon a level in point of acceptance with God, and intended to bring in publicans and harlots into the kingdom of God before them:—This sadly piqued the pride of Pharisees, who imagined they were in better terms with the Deity than the rest of the world, and much nigher the kingdom of God. The same reasons prevail with all the enemies of the atone∣ment.—They are chagrined because the atonement of Jesus Christ sets all their good virtues and moral
excellence aside, and brings them before God like other guilty men, who must either be accepted of on account of the righteouness of another, or perish for ever.—

THE meanness of Jesus, his outward character, made the Jews despise him, and the design of his death made them bate him. His example was op∣posite to the natural pride of the world, and these distinctions and differences that prevail so much a∣mong every sect of religionists, where every one has higher pretences to the favours of the Deity than ano∣ther; whereas Jesus made all the difference to con∣sist in bearing the cross, and self-denial. Human pride could not even admit his miracles to proceed from Divine power, because he himself did not ad∣mit of these differences:—So that when he made the blind to see, and the lame to walk, and raised the dead, and cured all manner of diseases, they still say, Is not this the carpenter's son? Because he did not establish the differences they were fond of, and loved to move in low life himself, they hated and despised him.—His death, that was designed to take away the sins of the world, they looked upon as the just demerit of his arrogance, in making himself equal with God; when he was one of the lowest of men. After his resurrection, when the fishers of Gallilee preached the doctrine of acceptance through his death, and shewed there was no salvation in any other; that it was only by believing in him that there was any difference among men in the sight of God, it made them gnash their teeth, and persecute them.

THIS is the root of all the enmity of men at the atonement of Jesus Christ: Because it sets all men in a level before God, in point of acceptance, they cannot see of what consequence their virtue and excellence is, unless it procure the Divine fa∣vour; they can assign no valuable end it is good for. There is either something too high or too
low about the character of Jesus for their appre∣hension. The humble pattern he set before men, piques their pride to look down to; and his Divine eminence above all creatures, and his equality with God, dazzles their pride to look up to. For this reason they have given him a middle charac∣ter, not quite consistent with either humanity or divinity.—They have raised him just as high as their pride can conceive human nature to be, and as near to God as they think it necessary, and made him a glorious creature with Divine attri∣butes: They have made him a glorious person, worthy to be followed in the shining part of his character; but not at all to be depended upon in point of acceptance with God.—There is a vast dif∣ference between the antient history of the life of Jesus Christ, and the modern draughts of it in later histories. The ancient history of his life, wrote by the apostles, informs us, when he was in his lowest state, He was the son of man that is in heaven, even at that time; that he was God as well as man in his low state of abasement:—That he still performed the same works with the father, and he and the father are one. But some writers of the history of his life in later times have found, That he was only a very “excellent man, raised up for a pattern to others in after-times, and that he was exceedingly ill used by the Almighty, who, tho' he had done no evil, yet made him suffer mortal sorrow; and die a ”shameful, painful, and ignominious death. The ancient history of Jesus Christ informs us, that he died for very weighty and sufficient reasons, that he might glorify God, and save sinners from eternal mi∣sery: That he might make his people acceptable unto God, and make both their persons and performan∣ces accepted before the Almighty: That he died to bring many sons unto glory. But modern discoveries in∣form us, That there were no such reasons of his
“death; but that he died, or fell a victim to the arbitrary caprice of the Deity, and the malice of ”wicked men. The whole description of his character that human pride hath invented, is only like that of an antient hero struggling with many difficulties, and overcoming them all; and for a re∣ward of his fortitude and virtue, receiving a subor∣dinate Deification above angels and men.

THE Lamb in the midst of the throne is only de∣spised, because his title is significant of the mortifi∣cation of all human pride and excellence.—By his humble life he has set such a meek and lowly pat∣tern to men, and by his death removed all distinc∣tions, in point of acceptance with God, that hu∣man pride, abhorring to be so much debased, takes its revenge in denying his Divine excellencies.— There is no other way of establishing human dif∣ferences in religion, but by undermining that prin∣ciple that removes all difference. That question, Who hath made thee to differ from another? is un∣answerable to human excellency, and therefore pride destroys the foundation upon which it is founded, and denies the true signification of this title of Jesus Christ, The Lamb in the midst of the throne. This title of our Redeemer is significant of his manner of life and teaching. He was in all things a pattern of meekness and true humility: And his advice to men was, Learn of me, for I am meek and lowly. Like a lamb for meekness, he was the eye-sore of the proud and vain, and for this rea∣son was hated by the leaders of the prevailing reli∣gion, who hated nothing so much as the cross and humility.—Had Jesus assumed a Divine character, and acted up to it in that light that pride views greatness, he would soon have found acceptance in the world, and Pharisees would not challenge him for saying, he was equal to God, if he had not sent them and their pride to the devil.

THE greatest adversaries of the atonement, and the Divine character of Jesus Christ, could easily allow him to be a Divine person, providing he had not, by assuming so high a character, obliged them to walk so low: And by debasing himself, urged hu∣mility by such grating arguments.—But seeing that he will have men to imitate him in lowliness and humility, so contrary to their sense of self-dependence, they think it but fit that they should be sharers with him in the glory of their acceptance with God. Tho' they will allow him to be the Lamb of God, as a pattern of meekness, they will not allow him to be a Lamb for a sin-offering. But to all true belie∣vers his title in the text has a noble and true signi∣fication. It shews that he is now accepted of, as our great High Priest; or in the words of Luke, Ex∣alted a Prince and a Saviour, to give repentance and remission of sin. He is represented as in the midst of the throne, as a king possessed of all power and authority, as Lord of the consciences of men.—And tho' he is now glorified, and possessed of all power and glory, he still sustains the character of our Re∣deemer, and his death is held as the ground of our acceptance with God.—Tho' in the midst of the throne, he is still the Lamb of God that takes away the sin of the world. This title signifies to us, that there is but one way of access to God to all men that shall be saved: That Jesus Christ, as dead and risen again, is the great and one thing needful; wor∣thy of our consideration both in this life and that which is to come. As the Lamb upon a throne of grace, he is the way of the sinners access to God, and the author of his acceptance while here; and as viewed upon a throne of glory, the administrator of all Divine gifts to his church and people in both their militant and triumphant state.—With the greatest propriety he deserves the title of, the Lamb in the midst of the throne.

2.
